questions.text:
Which of the following are not true regarding external hemorrhoids?
  1. Painful 
  2. Self-curing
  3. Banding is preferred
  4. Covered by squamous epithelium
  5. Commonly located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal
questions.solution:
External hemorrhoids are painful, self-curing and covered by squamous epithelium. The branches of the superior rectal vein, located at 3, 7, and 11 o’clock positions in the anal canal are common sites for internal hemorrhoids. Banding is preferred for internal hemorrhoids. 

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle fibres, and elastic connective tissue. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal Hemorrhoids 
  • External Hemorrhoids

Note: Repeated thrombosis leads to a semi-ripe black currant appearance of external hemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below.  Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
questions.solution:
The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.

The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Diphyllobothrium latum

Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Foster fuch’s spots are seen in_____.
questions.solution: Foster Fuchs spots are degenerative changes in the retina seen in pathological myopia. They are blackish spots due to retinal pigment epithelial hyperplasia that occur as a reparative response to choroidal neovascularization and sub-retinal hemorrhage. Linear breaks in Bruch's membrane, called lacquer cracks, may be seen as fine lines.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Perflation is not a type of mechanical ventilation. It is a type of natural ventilation.

Ventilation can be broadly classified as natural and mechanical:

Natural ventilation includes:

  • Perflation is the ventilation of a space achieved by allowing wind to blow through it and removing the obstacles for this to happen (e.g., opening windows and doors).
  • Aspiration occurs when there is an obstruction as wind bypasses it and creates a suction action.
  • Diffusion is the passage of air through small spaces or openings.
  • Cross-ventilation is when air is allowed a natural path through the space by providing openings at appropriate places, opposite each other.

The drawback of natural ventilation is that regulation of air quality is not possible.

Mechanical ventilation includes:

  • Exhaust ventilation utilizes exhaust fans placed high up near the roof on the external walls. A vacuum is created by which fresh air enters the ventilated space.
  • Plenum ventilation uses centrifugal fans to blow fresh air into the room and create a positive pressure, by which vitiated air is pushed out.
  • Balanced ventilation is the combination of both exhaust and plenum methods of ventilation.
  • Air conditioning can be done through mechanical ventilation. It is the simultaneous control of all or at least three factors that influence air quality in a confined room or space. These factors include temperature, humidity, air movement, distribution, dust, bacteria, odours and toxic gases.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given chest X-ray image depicts Chilaiditi sign, characterized by the anterior interposition of the colon between the liver and the right hemidiaphragm, which can mimic air under the diaphragm, leading to pseudo-pneumoperitoneum.

Chilaiditi sign is typically an incidental finding on imaging and is most often asymptomatic. However, when associated with symptoms such as abdominal pain and distension, it is referred to as Chilaiditi syndrome. 

An erect X-ray showing this sign may mislead clinicians into suspecting pneumoperitoneum, prompting unnecessary urgent surgical intervention, which is not required. To differentiate Chilaiditi syndrome from true pneumoperitoneum, a contrast-enhanced CT or a left lateral decubitus radiograph can be performed. In the left lateral decubitus view, distended colonic loops with haustral markings will be visible, showing that the air is within the bowel and not in the peritoneal cavity. 

Other conditions with the Chilaiditi sign are curvilinear pulmonary collapse, distended viscus, omental fat, and apposition of gas-distended bowel loops mimicking the double-wall sign.

Below is the chest X-ray and CT showing the presence of herniated bowel loops under the diaphragm.

Other options:

Option A: The CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows free intraperitoneal gas which is suggestive of pneumoperitoneum. The presence of free intra-abdominal gas almost always indicates perforation of a hollow viscus. Free intraperitoneal gas is also detectable under the hemidiaphragm on an erect chest X-ray as given below. 

Option B: The existence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum is referred to as pneumomediastinum. Gas may originate from the peritoneal cavity, lungs, trachea, central bronchi, oesophagus, or peritoneal cavity and travel to the neck or abdomen via the mediastinum.  Spinnaker sign (also called angel wing sign) is a radiographic sign seen in neonates with pneumomediastinum. The pressure from the collected gas displaces the two lobes of the thymic tissue upward and laterally from its normal position. This results in large, wedge-shaped opacities on radiograph resembling the spinnaker headsails of a boat.  Other signs of pneumomediastinum are the V sign of Naclerio and continuous diaphragm sign. 

Below is a chest X-ray showing spinnaker sign and CT showing the presence of pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: According to the WHO, which of the following tests cannot be used to confirm a case of swine flu?

choices.text: 4-fold rise in virus specific neutralizing antibodies

questions.solution:
ELISA is not included in the criteria for confirming a case of H1N1. 

The ELISA is an easy to perform, highly specific, and fairly sensitive diagnostic tool for the 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) virus infections. However, it is not included in the WHO 's list of confirmation tests.

According to WHO, 2009 pandemic (H1N1) virus infection is confirmed by one or more of the following tests:

  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
  • Viral culture
  • 4‐fold rise in H1N1 virus‐specific neutralizing antibodies

questions.text: In both eukaryotes and prokaryotes, gene expression is primarily regulated at the level of _____
questions.solution:
• In both eukaryotes and prokaryotes, gene expression is primarily regulated at the level of Transcription
  • Regulation of transcription, the initial step in all gene expression, is controlled by regulatory sequences of DNA, usually embedded in the noncoding regions of the genome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding drug resistance?

choices.text: In mutational drug resistance one drug resistance is seen at a time
Virulence is decreased in transferable resistance
Drug combinations can prevent Mutational drug resistance
High degree of resistance is seen in transferable drug resistance

questions.solution:
• Virulence is not decreased in transferable drug resistance.
  • Transferable drug resistance is widely seen in various pathogenic and commensal bacteria of humans.
  • The transfer can be effected readily in vitro, but in the normal gut, it is inhibited by factors such as Bile salts, anaerobic conditions, and alkaline pH.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Mutational and Transferable Drug Resistance

Mutational drug resistance

Transferable drug resistance

One drug resistance at a time

Multiple drug resistance

Low degree resistance

High degree resistance

Can be overcome by high drug dose

High dose ineffective

Drug combinations can prevent

Drug combinations cannot prevent

Resistance does not spread

Spreads to same or different species

Mutants may be defective

Not defective

Virulence may be low

Virulence not decreased

questions.text: A microbiologist is doing research about antigenic variations in parasites that occur within the host.  Which of the following parasites will exhibit this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation within the host. 

Trypanosoma brucei exhibits antigenic variation of its variant surface glycoproteins (VSGs) that coat the surface of the organism. There is a cyclical change in the type of VSG expressed every 7-10 days, which protects the trypanosomes from host antibodies against VSG. The parasites exhibiting antigenic variation include Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, Trypanosome brucei rhodesiense, Plasmodium spp. and Giardia lamblia.

 The following image shows Trypanosoma brucei.

The following image shows Plasmodium spp.

The following image shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia.

questions.text: While examining a patient’s pulse, you note a tapping impulse when you raise his arm above his head. Which of the following conditions would you not suspect in the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of water hammer pulse, which is not seen in left-sided heart failure.  

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse that collapses suddenly. This is because arterial pressure falls rapidly during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.

The various causes of the collapsing pulse include

  • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. 
  • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva
  • High-output states such as anemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism)

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: Where does the adult worm of Schistosoma mansoni live inside humans?
questions.solution:
Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein.

S. hematobium lives in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins.

S. japonicum lives in the superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region. They are also seen in the intrahepatic portal venules and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.

  SI Unit    Parameter measured
1. Gray  A. Dose equivalent
2. Becquerel B. Absorbed radiation

questions.solution:
The correctly matched SI units and parameters measured are as follows:

The common unit to measure radioactivity is curie. 

The common unit to measure total radiation exposure is roentgen.

questions.text:
All of the following patients with chronic myeloid leukemia are in the accelerated phase except:
  Peripheral blast cell count     Peripheral basophil count    
Patient 1         20%      15%
Patient 2         10%      25%
Patient 3         13%      21%
Patient 4         15%      14%
questions.solution:
A blast count ≥ 20% in peripheral blood is indicative of a blast crisis, not the accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

CML can be divided into three phases:

  • Chronic stable phase - Blasts < 10% in peripheral blood and bone marrow
  • Accelerated phase - any of the following:
    • Blasts comprising 10-19% of white blood cells (WBCs) in peripheral blood and/or bone marrow
    • Peripheral blood basophils ≥20%
    • Thrombocytopenia or thrombocytosis not responsive to therapy
    • Additional cytogenetic abnormalities in Philadelphia chromosome cells
  • Blast crisis:
    • Blasts ≥ 20% of peripheral blood WBCs or bone marrow
    • Extramedullary blast proliferation

Majority of the patients present in the chronic stable phase. Without effective treatment, CML in the chronic phase will eventually move into an accelerated phase at first and then into the blast phase.

While the accelerated phase was an aggressive form of CML, the benefit of tyrosine kinase inhibitors and disease monitoring has successfully led to the omission of the accelerated phase of CML as per the 5th edition of the WHO classification of hematolymphoid tumors.

questions.text: The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I is
questions.solution:
Growth hormone acts on the liver to form small proteins called “somatomedins”

  • Somatomedins increases bone growth in all aspect
  • Effects are similar to insulin, hence referred to as insulin-like growth factor (IGF).
  • Four types available:
    • Most important is somatomedin C, specifically referred to as “insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
    • Binds to carrier protein in blood
    • Hence, longer duration of action than growth hormone.
    • Half-life - about 20 Hrs (compared to growth hormone - 20 mins)
    • Blood concentration of IGF-1, follows the levels of growth hormone.
  • Growth effects of GH are mostly attributed to somatomedin (rather than its direct effect on bones & peripheral tissues)

questions.text: Which of the following is not the blood supply of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the posterior limb of the internal capsule and the recurrent artery of Heubner is not a part of its blood supply. 

The posterior limb of internal capsule is supplied by:
  • Charcot's artery (branch of middle cerebral artery)
  • Anterior choroidal artery (branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of internal capsule.

  • Anterior choroidal artery ( branch of internal carotid artery)
  • Posterolateral branches of posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: Feedback regulation is seen in ______

choices.text: The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins
Smell of food triggers secretion of salivary and gastric juices
An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels
The increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood pressure

questions.solution:
Feedback regulation is seen in the increased heart rate in response to a decrease in blood pressure. This is because, in feedback regulation, the homeostatic response (increased heart rate) occurs after the change (decrease in blood pressure) has occurred.

On the other hand, in feedforward regulation, the homeostatic responses take place before the change has occurred. This is done in anticipation of the change to minimize fluctuations. Examples of feedforward regulation include:

  • The increased heart rate that occurs in an athlete just before a sprint begins.
  • The smell of food triggers the secretion of salivary and gastric juices.
  • An increase in insulin before glucose absorption has raised blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the casualty after overdosing on anti-hypertensive medication. On examination, there are multiple cuts on her wrists. On further inquiry, her father says she has marked fluctuations in her mood with a history of unstable relationships and previous suicide attempts. What is the main defense mechanism used by these patients?
questions.solution:
The given history of repetitive self-destructive acts, unstable relationships and mood swings point towards a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder. The main defense mechanism such patients use is splitting i.e., distorting interpersonal relationships by considering each person to be either completely good or bad, with no middle ground.

Borderline personality disorder is classified under cluster B. It is characterized by an unstable affect, mood swings, marked impulsivity, unstable relationships, recurrent suicidal behavior, chronic feelings of emptiness or boredom, identity disturbance, and inappropriate anger. If stressed, the patient may become psychotic.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: Which is the HPV serotype most commonly associated with carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV 16 is the most common type associated with carcinoma cervix.

Associations between human papilloma virus (HPV) serotypes and carcinoma cervix:

  • Most common serotype - HPV 16
  • Most malignant serotype - HPV 18
  • Most specific serotype - HPV 18
  • Most common serotype associated with
    • Squamous cell carcinoma - HPV 16
    • Adenocarcinoma - HPV 18

Cancers caused by HPV:

  • Male - penile, oral, anal
  • Female - cervix, vagina, vulva

questions.text: A body of a hiker is found naked on a snow trail. It is hypothesized that he actively undressed just minutes prior to his death. Which of the following statements regarding this phenomenon is true?

choices.text: Indicator of mild to moderate hypothermia
Associated with increased carbon monoxide in circulation
The mechanism is that of peripheral vasodilation

questions.solution:
The given phenomenon of paradoxical undressing is likely due to peripheral vasodilation.

It is a phenomenon encountered in severe hypothermic states. It is characterized by the act of active undressing, despite low ambient temperatures. Proposed mechanisms are:

  • Reflex vasoconstriction, which happens in the first stage of hypothermia, leads to paralysis of the vasomotor center thus giving rise to the sensation that the body temperature is higher than it really is.
  • Vasodilatation happens when cold-induced paralysis of the nerves in the vessel walls gives an absurd feeling of heat.

Other associated features include:

  • Bruises and scratches of the knees, shanks, and upper limbs caused by late-phase attempts at crawling. 
  • The hide-and-die phenomenon in some cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about composting?

choices.text: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
Mechanical composting uses a controlled environment
Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens

questions.solution:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process.

Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens.

Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed.

Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old singer complains of a change in her voice. Direct laryngoscopy procedure shows the presence of laryngeal cysts. Which part of the larynx does the cyst arise from?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal cysts arise in the aryepiglottic folds. 

These are benign conditions that need no intervention unless they are large. Large cysts can cause airway obstruction/change in voice. These require immediate aspiration followed by deroofing.

questions.text: In the Golgi apparatus, lysosomal enzymes are tagged with the __________residue to direct them to the lysosomes.
questions.solution:
Mannose-6-phosphate is a marker for the delivery of lysosomal enzymes.

  • Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles containing roughly 40 different acid hydrolases (i.e., enzymes that function best in acidic pH ≤5).
  • These hydrolases include proteases, nucleases, lipases, glycosidases, phosphatases, and sulfatases.
  • Lysosomal enzymes are initially synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) lumen and then tagged with a mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) residue within the Golgi apparatus.
  • Such M6P-modified proteins are subsequently delivered to lysosomes through trans-Golgi vesicles that express M6P receptors.

questions.text: Where is the lower part of the vagina derived from?
questions.solution:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus. 

Option A: The ovary and the testis are derived from the genital ridge. 

Option C: The upper part of the vagina is derived from the paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct. The uterus develops from the fusion of the right and left paramesonephric ducts in the midline. 

Option D: The labia minora and the ventral aspect of the penis are derived from the urogenital folds.

Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra

 		 Genital tubercle

Urethral and paraurethral glands /Skene's glands

questions.text: In a patient with influenza, there is decreased expression of MHC proteins on the surface of the virus-infected cells. Which component of the immune system acts on such cells?
questions.solution:
Natural killer cells (NK cells) act on virus-infected cells with reduced MHC expression. 

NK cells are a subtype of lymphocytes that kill damaged or infected cells. NK cells express CD16 and CD56. Their action is inhibited when MHC I is expressed on normal cells. This prevents NK Cells from killing normal cells. In the presence of a viral infection or malignancy, MHC expression of a cell is reduced. Thus, NK cells get activated and kill virus-infected/tumor cells. NK cells also secrete cytokines (IFN-γ) which activate macrophages (option B) for destruction of ingested microbes. 

Other options:

Option A: Cytotoxic T cells act when cells expressing MHC I present endogenous antigens.

Option D: Helper T cells act when cells expressing MHC II (antigen-presenting cells) present exogenous antigens.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung’s disease?
questions.solution:
• Patients with Hirschsprung’s disease have an increased frequency of mutations in several genes, including those coding for glial cell line–derived neurotrophic factor (GCDNF); its receptor REarranged during Transfection (RET), or its coreceptor Gfra-1 (GDNF family receptor alpha-1).
  • GDNF promotes the survival, proliferation, and migration of neural crest cells in culture.
  • GDNF is expressed in the gut in advance of migrating neural crest cells and is chemoattractive for neural crest cells in culture.
  • Gene mutations in chromosomes 10 and 13, family history, and Down’s syndrome are also factors associated with Hirschsprung’s disease.

questions.text: What is the use of MIDAS questionnaire?

choices.text: To help decide treatment of migraine

questions.solution:
The Migraine Disability Assessment Score (MIDAS) questionnaire was put together to help measure the impact of migraine on patients' lives.

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical therapy. What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.solution:
An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy.

Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer) urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuated bacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells.

Option d: Mw vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is also used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category II tuberculosis.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair

choices.text: A-Normal liver,B-Alcoholic steatosis, C- Micronodular cirrhosis, D-Alcoholic hepatitis

questions.solution:
A-Normal liver

B-Alcoholic steatosis:

  • A mix of small and large fat droplets
  • Ethanol inhibits fatty acid metabolism, leading to lipolysis and increased triglyceride. These triglycerides accumulate and causes steatosis. Liver enzymes are normal at this stage

C-Micronodular cirrhosis:

  • The average nodule size is 3 mm in this close-up view, typical of the “micronodular” cirrhosis of alcoholic liver disease

D-Alcoholic hepatitis:

  • Mallory-Denk bodies: These are usually present as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. These inclusions are a characteristic, but not specific, feature of alcoholic liver disease.

 

High-magnification micrograph of a Mallory body (black arrow), as seen in steatohepatitis. Liver biopsy. H&E stain.

Mallory bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions that are aggregates of denatured keratin filaments. They have a twisted rope-like appearance. On trichrome stain, they appear green/dark brown. 

World liver day is observed on the 19th of April, to spread awareness about the liver, the role it plays in our body and liver-related diseases.

Also note, World Hepatitis Day, observed on July 28 every year, aims to raise global awareness of hepatitis.

questions.text: Otto veraguth fold is seen in ______
questions.solution: Otto Veraguth fold is a physical sign of depression wherein there is a triangular fold in the nasal corner of upper eyelid.

questions.text: What is the site of synthesis of O–linked glycoproteins?
questions.solution:
O–linked glycoproteins are synthesized in the Golgi apparatus by the sequential transfer of sugars from their nucleotide carriers to the protein.

O-linked glycoproteins are proteins attached to a sugar (eg: N-acetylgalactosamine) through an O-glycosidic linkage between the hydroxyl side chain of serine/threonine and the sugar. Examples of O-linked glycoproteins include mucins, proteoglycans and collagens.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the pathogenetic hallmark for filovirus infections?

choices.text: There is a pronounced suppression of immune system.
DIC causes severe imbalance in the clotting system.
Extensive necrosis/hypoxic infarcts are seen in target tissues, particularly the gonads, kidneys, liver, and spleen.
It is associated with severe lymphocytosis.

questions.solution:
Severe lymphopenia is seen in patients with filovirus infections.

Filoviruses are a long, thread-like virus, hence the name.

Predominantly pleomorphic filaments but also assume torus- or 6-like shapes (width, ~80 nm; average length, ≥790 nm). 

Ebola virus and Marburg viruses, which cause hemorrhagic fever, belong to the genus filovirus.

  • The first targets of filovirus are local macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • One of the pathogenetic hallmarks of filovirus infections is a pronounced suppression of the immune system. It causes severe disturbance of the clotting system and the impairment of vascular integrity. Disseminated intravascular coagulation is the cause of the severe imbalance in the clotting system of filovirus-infected patients.

The FDA recently approved Ervebo, the first FDA-approved vaccine for the prevention of Ebola virus disease (EVD), caused by Zaire ebolavirus in individuals 18 years of age and older.

questions.text: A mother brings her 1-year-old child to the hospital with complaints that he turns blue while breastfeeding. It resolves when he assumes a squatting position. On examination, a cleft palate is seen. Labs show hypocalcemia. Which of the following abnormalities is expected to be seen in the lymphoid organs?

choices.text: Decreased size of germinal centres of lymph nodes
Decreased size of paracortical areas of lymph nodes
Increased size of the peri arteriolar lymphoid sheath of spleen

questions.solution:
Turning blue on breastfeeding with resolution on squatting describes a tet-spell or a cyanotic spell, indicating a congenital cardiac defect. Cleft palate, cardiac defects and hypocalcemia (parathyroid hypoplasia/aplasia) suggest a diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. In this disorder, a decreased size of paracortical areas of lymph nodes is noted. 

DiGeorge syndrome is characterised by thymic aplasia, causing a deficiency of T cells and absent cell-mediated immunity. Thus, paracortical areas of lymph nodes and periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, where T cells reside, are reduced in size. B cells are usually not affected. 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed with a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Circumcision is avoided in these patients
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Usually associated with a ventral deformity of the erect penis
Does not cause obstruction in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed ("hooded prepuce") in hypospadias.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of a ventrally (underside of penis or perineum) placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis).

Types of hypospadias (according to meatal location):

  • Anterior (Distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (Proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Note:

In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the foreskin may be used later for reconstruction.

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding alpha helix?

choices.text: Stability of an alpha helix arises primarily from the peptide bond.
A complete turn of an alpha helix contains 3.6 amino acyl residues.
Pitch of the helix is 0.54 nm.
Large numbers of charged amino acids disrupt the helix.

questions.solution:
Alpha helix is stabilized primarily by intra-chain hydrogen bonds. 

Alpha helix is the most common and stable secondary structure of protein. It is a rigid, right-handed spiral. A complete turn of the helix contains an average of 3.6 aminoacyl residues. The rise per turn of the helix (pitch) is 0.54nm. 

Large numbers of charged amino acids (glutamate, aspartate, histidine, lysine, and arginine) disrupt the helix by forming ionic bonds or by electrostatically repelling each other.

questions.text: Which of these is not a marker of bone resorption?
questions.solution:
Serum bone specific alkaline phosphatase is a marker for bone formation.

Other markers for bone formation are:

  • Serum osteocalcin

  • Serum type 1 procollagen (C-terminal/N-terminal)

 

Markers for bone resorption are:

  • Urinary hydroxyproline

  • Urinary total pyridinoline (PYD)

  • Urinary free deoxypyridinoline (DPD)

  • Urinary collagen type 1 cross-linked N-Telopeptide(NTX)

  • Urinary or serum collagen type 1 cross-linked C-Telopeptide (CTX)

  • Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b

questions.text: What is the uteroplacental blood flow at term?
questions.solution: The uteroplacental blood flow at term is 500-750 ml/min.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is in favor of tyrosinemia. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).

Note:

Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulant of choice in a patient, who  is undergoing  a surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass ?
questions.solution:
Heparin remains the agent of choice for surgery requiring cardiopulmonary bypass.

Other options : 

  • Fondaparinux is not used because of the risk of catheter thrombosis, a complication caused by catheter-induced activation of factor XII.
  • Lepirudin is used for treating thrombosis in  case of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • Dabigatran is used in treatment of acute venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the figure. What is his expiratory reserve volume (in liters)?
questions.solution:
Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity - Residual Volume

In the given spirogram,

  • Functional Residual Capacity = 3L
  • Residual Volume = 1L 

Therefore,

Expiratory Reserve Volume = Functional Residual Capacity – Residual Volume = 3-1 = 2

Note:

The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after the most forceful expiration.

The functional residual capacity equals the expiratory reserve volume plus the residual volume. This capacity is the amount of air that remains in the lungs at the end of normal expiration

The expiratory reserve volume is the maximum extra volume of air that can be expired by forceful expiration after the end of a normal tidal expiration.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Normal Value

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

∼3 L

questions.text: A gasteroenterologist is performing an esophagoscopy in a patient with severe acid reflux. At which level will he encounter its diaphragmatic constriction?
questions.solution:
The esophageal hiatus is located at the level of the T10 vertebra, and it forms a normal constriction of the esophagus. It transmits the following:

  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels and
  • Some lymphatic vessels

Clinical significance:

Anatomical constrictions of the esophagus are important landmarks in esophagoscopy. These are 4 in number and located at a distance from the upper incisors as follows:

  1. 15cm - Cricopharyngeus muscle
  2. 22.5cm - Aortic arch
  3. 27.5cm - Left bronchus
  4. 37.5cm - Diaphragmatic opening

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with loose stools and right lower abdominal pain for the past 6 months. Endoscopy was done which showed skip lesions with a cobblestone appearance. Histopathological examination showed aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses. Which of the following genes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. It is strongly associated with mutations in the nucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) gene.

Crohn's disease occurs due to the host response against microbes. NOD2 encodes an intracellular protein that binds to bacterial peptidoglycans and activates the NF-κB pathway. Antibodies against the bacterial protein flagellin may be seen in NOD2-associated disease. 

Other Crohn's disease-related genes are autophagy-related 16-like (ATG16L1), and immunity-related GTPase M (IRGM), which are critical for cellular responses to intracellular bacteria.

Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect all parts of the GIT. The following microscopic changes may be seen: 

  • Aphthoid ulcerations 
  • Focal crypt abscesses 
  • Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas

Note: Ulcerative colitis-associated genes are ECM1 and HNFA.

questions.text: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is a gamma motor neuron.  

Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” 

Option (b):

The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the motor unit.

Option (c):

A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure.

Option (d):

A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in patients with adenocarcinoma of the lung with EGFR mutation?
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinomas with EGFR mutation are exquisitely sensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of the EGFR signal pathway such as gefitinib and erlotinib.

Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF.

Option B: Paclitaxel- a taxane, is a plant alkaloid and chemotherapeutic agent.

Option C: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective in the treatment of CML and GIST.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lump in the left breast as shown in the image below. Biopsy done revealed increased stromal cellularity with typical leaflike architecture. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Treatment is wide excision with margin
Originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology report point to malignant cystosarcoma phyllodes, which metastasize via the bloodstream. Metastasis to lymph nodes is rare.

Phyllodes tumor also known as a sero-cystic disease of Brodie or cystosarcoma phyllodes, originates from hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. It is usually a benign condition and affects women >40 years of age, but can be seen in younger women. Sometimes, may develop malignant transformation.

Clinical features:

  1. Large, sometimes massive, with an unevenly bosselated surface
  2. Ulceration of overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis
  3. Remains mobile on the chest wall

There is no role of FNAC in phyllodes tumor. Histopathology of the lump biopsy shows increased stromal cellularity, overgrowth, and typical leaflike architecture.

Tumors are treated by excision with margins of at least 2 cm to prevent local recurrence.

Large or malignant phyllodes tumors may require a mastectomy. The axillary dissection is not recommended because axillary lymph nodes rarely get involved.

Note: Malignant phyllodes tumors contain liposarcomatous or rhabdomyosarcomatous elements rather than fibrosarcomatous elements.

questions.text: In which of the following types of cartilages is type 1 collagen present?
questions.solution:
Type I collagen is present in fibrocartilage.

  • Fibrocartilage (also known as white fibrocartilage) contains both type I and type II collagen. 
  • Hyaline and elastic cartilage contains only type II collagen

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN4 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma is not associated with MEN4 syndrome, but it is associated with MEN2 syndrome.

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: Which of the following statements about theophylline is not correct?

choices.text: Increase in dose is required in cardiopulmonary disease
Decreases the breakdown of cAMP in smooth muscles
Increase in dose is required in smokers

questions.solution:
A decrease in dose of theophylline is required in cardiopulmonary disease. This is because reduced clearance of theophylline is seen in liver disease, pneumonia, and heart failure.

In smokers, clearance of theophylline is increased due to the induction of CYP1A2 enzyme. 

Theophylline is a non-selective phosphodiesterase inhibitor that decreases the breakdown of cAMP levels in smooth muscles resulting in bronchodilation.

questions.text: In a patient requiring invasive BP monitoring, which is the preferred artery used for canulation and measurement?
questions.solution:
Radial artery is the preferred artery for invasive blood pressure monitoring because of ease of cannulation, presence of collateral blood flow and less associated complications.

Before cannulating the radial artery, it is essential to perform a modified Allen’s test in order to determine the adequacy of collateral flow to the hand.

The other arteries which can be used for invasive blood pressure monitoring are ulnar, brachial, axillary, and femoral arteries and less commonly dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, and superficial temporal arteries.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the labor room at 39 weeks of gestation. On examination, you notice the fetal head has appeared at the vulva. Which of the following maneuvers can be used to assist the delivery of the head?
questions.solution:
Ritgen's maneuver is done for delivery of head in normal labor.

This maneuver is done when the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of >5 cm. A towel is draped and a gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum. The other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput.

This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the septum).

The contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery, which supplies nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

This question was asked in recent AIIMS and NEET examinations, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: A researcher is calculating the child survival indices for different populations. Which of the following should he use for calculating the same?
questions.solution: The under-5 mortality rate is used in the calculation of the child survival index. It is calculated as (1000 – Under-5 mortality rate)/10.

questions.text: Which inhalational anesthetic agent causes the maximum decline in hepatic blood flow?
questions.solution:
Maximum decline in hepatic blood flow is caused by halothane.

All volatile anesthetics decrease hepatic blood flow but halothane causes the maximum decrease. Hepatic artery vasoconstriction and increase in hepatic arterial resistance are seen with halothane. 

Halothane also reduces hepatic oxygen delivery and hepatic venous oxygen saturation. This is because of the greater reduction in cardiac output caused by halothane than the other volatile agents.

Hepatic arterial buffer response(HABF) is an autoregulatory mechanism in the liver. When portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. Halothane disrupts this regulatory mechanism, which is best preserved with sevoflurane or isoflurane.

Desflurane and sevoflurane have the least significant effects on total hepatic blood flow and oxygen delivery. Sevoflurane is considered equal to or better than isoflurane in preserving hepatic arterial blood flow and hepatic oxygen delivery.

questions.text: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
questions.solution:
Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors. 

Related Pearl: Cell wall synthesis inhibitors (mnemonic "BBC Van")

BBC Van:

  • Beta lactams
  • Bacitracin
  • Cycloserine
  • Vancomycin
  • Fosfomycin

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with schizoaffective disorder was admitted for worsening hallucinations and started on chlorpromazine. A few days later, he developed a fever, unsteady gait, and tremors. On examination, BP was 146/88 mmHg. PR was 102 and bilateral hyporeflexia is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and history of treatment with a phenothiazine is suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome occurs in patients treated with phenothiazines. It can present with tremors, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, and hypertension. It may also cause autonomic storm.

Option A: Serotonin syndrome is always associated with concurrent GI symptoms.

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia means involuntary, repetitive body movements. It is a symptom of antipsychotic medication.

Option D: Malignant hyperthermia occurs due to inhalational anesthetics. 

 

Related Pearl: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Neuroleptic Malignant syndrome
Signs/ symptoms

Fever (sometimes > 40o C)

Mental status changes

Motor symptoms:

  • Muscular rigidity (generalised)
  • Dystonia
  • Akinesia

Autonomic symptoms:    

  • Tachycardia/arrhythmias
  • Labile blood pressure         
  • Tachypnea
  • Diaphoresis

Mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion.
Precipitating factors

Antipsychotics (typical and atypical)

Antiemetics (ex: Promethazine, Metoclopramide) 

Withdrawal of Antiparkinsonian drugs (dopamine agonists) 

Infection 

Surgery
Investigations

Elevated WBC count, creatinine phosphokinase (CPK), myoglobin, and liver enzymes.

Myoglobinuria may be seen in patients who develop acute renal failure.
Treatment 
  • Stop neuroleptic agents and start dopaminergic agonists
  • Supportive care (hydration, cooling)
  • Dantrolene or Bromocriptine
  • Amantadine may be used in some cases.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy may also be used. 

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

 Syndrome
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome
Anticholinergic syndrome

questions.text: Cancer-'The emperor of all maladies spares no one'. Which of the following is the most common childhood malignancy?
questions.solution:
Leukemias are the most common childhood malignancies. Among these, acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common, accounting for about 77% of childhood leukemias. 

Most commons in childhood malignancies:

  • Second most common malignancy in childhood: Brain tumor
  • Third most common malignancy in children: Lymphoma
  • Most common solid tumor in children: Brain tumor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding liver enzymes is true?

choices.text: ALT is raised to >1000 IU/L in cirrhosis
Absolute levels of aminotransferases correlate with the prognosis
AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
AST:ALT ratio >1 is seen in chronic viral hepatitis

questions.solution:
AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in NAFLD (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease).

The AST:ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:

AST:ALT Condition
<1 Chronic viral hepatitis, Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
>1 Cirrhosis
>2:1

Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease

Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.
>3:1 Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

Option A: Patients with cirrhosis have only mildly elevated or even normal levels of serum transaminases.

Option B: Absolute levels of aminotransferases are not used for predicting prognosis. This is because there is a poor correlation between the degree of liver cell damage and the levels of aminotransferases.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules?

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells.
Peptide-binding site for MHC class I is α1/α2 groove.
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens.
β2 of MHC II binds to CD4 on TH cells.

questions.solution:
MHC class I presents endogenous antigens, while MHC class II presents exogenous antigens.

The following table shows the differentiating characteristics of MHC Class I and MHC Class II antigens.

MHC CLASS I

MHC CLASS II

Present on all nucleated cells ( except sperms) and platelets

Present on antigen presenting cells

Presents exogenous antigen to CD4+ T cells

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway

Peptide binds to α1/α2 groove

Peptide binds to α1/β1 groove

CD8 molecules bind cytotoxic T cells

CD4 molecules bind helper T cells

questions.text: A middle-aged man with liver metastasis and altered LFT is posted for a surgery. What would be the opioid of choice in him?
questions.solution:
Opioid of choice in patients with compromised hepatic function is remifentanil.

Remifentanil is hydrolyzed by plasma and tissue esterases and hence its metabolism is independent of hepatic function.

Other opioids like fentanyl, alfentanil, and sufentanil are metabolized by the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct relationship between variance and standard deviation?

choices.text: Variance = square root of standard deviation
Standard deviation = square root of variance

questions.solution:
Standard deviation is the square root of variance.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with schizoaffective disorder and was prescribed a drug. Soon after initiation of therapy, she developed galactorrhea and dysmenorrhea, and her prolactin level was 171.6ng/mL. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Risperidone causes the maximum rise in prolactin levels and has the highest potential to cause hyperprolactinemia among the atypical antipsychotics.

Risperidone is an antagonist of 5-HT2A and D2 receptors. The combined use of risperidone and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) can also result in a significant elevation of prolactin with galactorrhea and breast enlargement.

questions.text: Methotrexate was administered to a patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy. At what serum beta hCG levels will this drug be most effective?
questions.solution:
Methotrexate is most effective when given at β hCG levels are <5000 IU/L.

Methotrexate is given at a dose of 50 mg/m2 of body surface area. Monitoring is done by measuring β hCG levels on days 4 and 7. If the decline is ≥15% of the initial value, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. If the decline is <15%, a 2nd dose of methotrexate is given on day 7.

questions.text:
In a patient with massive haemorrhage, damage control surgery is being performed. What does this consist of?
  1. Arrest of hemorrhage
  2. Sepsis control
  3. Protection from further injury
  4. Performing immediate definitive repair
  5. Administering colloids for volume expansion
questions.solution:
Damage Control Surgery refers to performing limited surgical intervention in order to arrest hemorrhage, control sepsis, and protect from further injury.

This concept of tailoring the operation to match the patient’s physiology and staged procedures to prevent physiological exhaustion is called Damage Control Surgery.

Furthermore, definitive repairs are delayed and not until the patient is hemodynamically stable and physiologically capable of sustaining the procedure. Crystalloid and colloid infusions are limited in order to avoid dilutional coagulopathy.

The term Damage Control Surgery is borrowed from the military, which ensures the continued functioning of a damaged ship above conducting complete repairs which would prevent a rapid return to battle.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man had trauma to the right foot, following which he complained of difficulty in walking. Examination showed collapse of the medial longitudinal arch. Injury to all of the following structures may cause the given condition except:
questions.solution:
Peroneus longus muscle maintains the lateral longitudinal arch and not the medial arch.

The muscles, tendons, and aponeurosis that maintain the longitudinal arches of the foot are of two types:

  • Slings: These structures help to maintain the arch by suspending the arch from above.
  • Tie beams (bowstrings): These are present between the anterior and posterior pillars and help maintain the arch by preventing the separation of the pillars.

Related Pearl: Comparative features of the medial and lateral longitudinal arches of the foot.

Superior articular surface of Calcaneum (at the leveled Subtalar joint)

Plantar surface of calcaneum posteriorly and Heads of 4th, 5th metatarsals anteriorly
