questions.text: Which of the following is not implicated in the pathogenesis of irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Decreased colonic motor potentials are not implicated in the pathogenesis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). On the contrary, increased colonic motor potentials are seen.

The pathogenesis of IBS is poorly understood. However, the following have been implicated in its pathogenesis:

  • Increased colonic motor potentials lead to increased high-amplitude propagating contractions (HAPCs) which causes diarrhea.
  • Visceral hypersensitivity leads to exaggerated sensory responses to visceral stimulation by food. This explains the postprandial symptoms in IBS.
  • CNS dysregulation - dysfunctional activation of the mid-cingulate cortex and prefrontal lobes leads to increased perception of visceral pain.
  • Abnormal serotonin pathways - serotonin-containing enterochromaffin cells are increased in IBS patients.
  • Altered gut flora

questions.text: All of the following statements are true except that _____

choices.text: Costovertebral joints and costotransverse joints are plain synovial joints
First 7 sternocostal joints are synovial joints
Joints between manubrium and body of sternum is symphysis

questions.solution:
Most of the joints in thoracic cavity (interchondral, sternocostal, costovertebral, and costotransverse joints) are plain synovial because thoracic cavity needs to expand during inspiration. However, there are some exceptions:

  • 1st sternocostal joint - Synarthrosis (fibrous), inaccurately called as synchondrosis.
  • Interchondral joint between the ninth and tenth cartilages is never synovial and sometimes absent.
  • Costochondral joints are primary cartilagenous joints (synchondrosis).
  • Midline joints like manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints are secondary cartilagenous joints, which are of the symphysis type.

questions.text: Artery passing through the structure marked in the diagram below is a branch of:
questions.solution:
The image shown is the ligament of head of the femur and the artery passing through it is the foveal artery/ artery of ligament of head of femur. It is derived from the acetabular branch of obturator artery.

The blood supply of the femoral head is derived from an arterial ring (trochanteric anastomosis) around the neck of femur constituted by:

  • Medial circumflex femoral arteries 
  • Lateral circumflex femoral arteries
  • Superior and inferior gluteal vessels (minor contributions)

questions.text: HMP shunt can occur at all of the following sites except:
questions.solution:
HMP shunt pathway can not occur in muscles because muscle tissue is deficient in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the oxidative phase of the pathway.

HMP shunt pathway takes place in the following:

  • Liver
  • Adipose tissue
  • Adrenal cortex
  • Thyroid
  • Erythrocytes
  • Testis
  • Lactating mammary glands

Given below is the HMP shunt pathway.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Paget's disease. X-ray of the patient is given below. In which phase of the disease is the patient at?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows blade of grass deformity seen in the osteolytic phase of Paget's disease.

An initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization. Radiographically, this manifests as an advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass or flame shaped lesion.

The second phase is a period of very active bone formation and resorption. It is characterised by normal lamellar bone replaced with haphazard (woven) bone.

In the final sclerotic phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a hard, dense, less vascular mosaic bone, which represents the so-called burned-out phase of Paget’s disease.

The arrow mark in the following image indicates blade of grass appearance.

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of photophobia and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. Investigation reveals Haab’s striae seen in the eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This neonate  with complaints of photophobia and watering with large cornea and Haab's striae is suggestive of buphthalmos. Haab’s striae are horizontal/circumferential breaks in Descemet’s membrane seen in buphthalmos.

Buphthalmos (Bull-like eyes) is an enlargement of the eyeball seen in true congenital and infantile glaucoma, usually when the disease onset is before 3 years.

The image given below shows Haab's striae and a child having buphthalmos in congenital glaucoma.

Note: Vogt's striae are vertical, fine, whitish lines (folds/tears) in Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.

The image given below shows Vogt's striae.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows collarette scales, which are a characteristic feature of pityriasis rosea.

Collarette refers to a scale with an adherent outer border and detachable inner border. It appears like a rim around the lesion as seen below.

Related Pearl: Types of scales associated with dermatological conditions

Types of Scales and Associated Diseases

Type of Scale

Associated Disease

Collarette scale

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

Fish-like scales

They are seen in ichthyosis vulgaris (ichthyos - fish). Ichthyotic scales are large and polygonal.

Silvery scales

They are characteristic of processes involving parakeratosis, especially psoriasis. The silvery color is due to the reflection of light at several air–keratin interfaces.

Mica-like scales

They are seen in Pityriasis lichenoides. The lesions are polymorphic with some showing hemorrhagic crusting and adherent scales.

Yellow / greasy scales

Seborrheic dermatitis

Leaf-like scales

Pemphigus foliaceous

Powdery, branny, fine scales

Pityriasis versicolor

questions.text: Identify the device shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shown above is of Lack's circuit, which is a co-axial modification of Mapleson's A circuit.

Co-axial circuits have two tubings, one inner and one outer tubing (arranged co-axially).

Lack's circuit has:

  • Inner expiratory tubing: carries exhaust gases out through APL valve
  • Outer inspiratory tubing: carries fresh gas flow to the patient

Magill's circuit (Mapleson A) designed by Sir Ivan Magill, best suited for spontaneous ventilation.

Jackson and Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is a modification of Ayre's T piece. Best suited for children under 20 kg.

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Which among the following enzymes can utilize both NAD+ and NADP+?
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is unusual in that it can use either NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.

NAD+ is used primarily in oxidative deamination (the simultaneous loss of ammonia coupled with the oxidation of the carbon skeleton).

NADPH is used in reductive amination (the simultaneous gain of ammonia coupled with the reduction of the carbon skeleton).

questions.text: A gallium-67 scan was performed on a patient and showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scan shows the classic panda sign seen in sarcoidosis. This occurs because of the symmetrical uptake of Gallium-67 in the nasopharynx, lacrimal glands, and parotid glands, reflecting the bilateral involvement of the glands in sarcoidosis.

Other signs seen in sarcoidosis are:

  • The lambda sign refers to bilateral hilar and right paratracheal lymphadenopathy (seen on FDG PET Scan/ Ga scintigraphy). 
  • Garland triad or 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbroker's sign is a lymph node enlargement pattern that is seen in sarcoidosis (seen on chest X-ray as shown below).
  • Galaxy sign (sarcoid galaxy) represents a coalescent granuloma seen in a minority of patients with pulmonary sarcoidosis, seen on HRCT as shown below

questions.text: Which of the following statements about ifosfamide is false?

choices.text: Chloroacetaldehyde is the metabolite of ifosfamide

questions.solution:
Ifosfamide is more neurotoxic than cyclophosphamide. It causes greater platelet suppression, nephrotoxicity, and urothelial damage when compared to cyclophosphamide.

Ifosfamide is a nitrogen mustard (alkylating agent). It is metabolized by hydroxylation by cytochrome P450 enzymes. Chloroacetaldehyde is a metabolite of ifosfamide that is responsible for severe neurological adverse effects.

questions.text: In the circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the _____.
questions.solution:
In circulatory system, the highest velocity of blood flow is in the aorta.

  • The velocity of blood flow is inversely proportional to vascular cross-sectional area.

v= velocity
F= blood flow through the vessel
A=vascular cross-sectional area

  • Aorta has the least cross sectional area (4.5 cm2) and capillaries have the maximum cross sectional area (4500 cm2). Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity is highest in aorta and least in capillaries.

questions.text: When does red degeneration of fibroids most commonly occur?
questions.solution:
Red/carneous degeneration occurs most commonly during the second trimester of pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding multiple sclerosis?

choices.text: It is an acute inflammatory condition of neurons
It is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system
It may also involve the peripheral nervous system
The condition is always benign and resolves spontaneously

questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system. It is characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (scarring), and neuronal loss.

The peripheral nervous system is spared in MS.

The course of the disease may be relapsing-remitting or progressive. The clinical course of manifestation can be variable ranging from a benign condition to a rapidly evolving and incapacitating disease.

questions.text: A patient with a pancreatic neoplasm undergoes cyst fluid aspiration. The aspirated fluid stains positive for mucin and shows elevated levels of amylase and CEA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Positive mucin staining, elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and elevated amylase levels are seen in cases of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN).

Cyst fluid analysis of various pancreatic cystic neoplasms:

Characteristics Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN) Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN)
Cytology

Scant glycogen-rich cells, with positive periodic acid–Schiff stain

Sheets and clusters of columnar, mucin-containing cells

Tall, columnar, mucin-containing cells
Mucin stain Negative Positive Positive
Amylase Low Low High
CEA Low High High

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with the change in genetic material?
questions.solution:
Inversion involves only a rearrangement of the genetic material. There is no change in the genetic material.

It occurs as a result of two breaks within a single chromosome. The intervening segment between the breaks gets inverted and reincorporated. It is of two types:

  • Paracentric - inversion involving only one arm of the chromosome
  • Pericentric - inversion involving opposite sides of the centromere

Inversions are often fully compatible with normal development.

Transversions are mutations where a purine base pair is replaced by a pyrimidine or vice versa.

questions.text: After how many days of primary infestation with a scabies mite is a person likely to develop pruritus?
questions.solution:
The incubation period of scabies is 3–4 weeks (21-28 days).

However, reinfection of a previously cured individual may provoke immediate symptoms.

questions.text: Amussat’s sign is an intimal tear of______
questions.solution:
• Amussat’s sign is an intimal tear of the carotid artery.
  • Important post-mortem findings of hanging:
    • Internal:
      • The fluidity of blood.
      • Tissues under ligature will be dry, pale and glistening.
      • There may be intimal tears of the carotid artery (Amussat’s sign).
      • Fracture of hyoid is seen in 15-20% of cases. Fracture of the thyroid cartilage and tracheal rings may be seen. There may be congestion and ecchymoses in trachea, epiglottis, esophagus, and larynx. All these injuries are more common in strangulation because strangulation is more violent than hanging causing more severe injury to neck structures.

questions.text: An infant is being evaluated for multiple fractures over the last 3 months. On examination, hydrocephaly, cranial nerve defects, and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Imaging reveals generalized sclerosis and a bone-in-bone appearance. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme to be deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteopetrosis. It occurs due to autosomal recessive defects in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase II.

Carbonic anhydrase II is required by osteoclasts and renal tubular cells to generate protons from carbon dioxide and water (acidification). The absence of carbonic anhydrase II prevents osteoclasts from acidifying the resorption pit and dissolution of calcium hydroxyapatite within the bone matrix. It also blocks the acidification of urine by the renal tubular cells. This leads to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis.

Due to deficient osteoclast activity, bones involved by osteopetrosis lack a medullary canal giving it a bone-in-bone appearance. The ends of long bones are bulbous (Erlenmeyer flask deformity) and misshapen. The neural foramina are small and compress the exiting nerves, leading to cranial nerve palsies. 

Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to leukopenia and prominent hepatosplenomegaly. As carbonic anhydrase II is widely expressed, mutations of this gene result in a condition called marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false with regard to autoimmune hepatitis?

choices.text: Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows antinuclear antibodies (ANA).
It can progress to liver failure.
Inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of plasma cells.

questions.solution:
Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-liver kidney microsomal autoantibodies (anti-LKM1) and anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies not ANA.

Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-nuclear (ANA), anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) and anti–soluble liver antigen / liver pancreas antigen (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies. It less commonly shows anti-mitochondrial (AMA) antibodies.

Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by continuing hepatocellular necrosis and inflammation. It can progress to cirrhosis and liver failure.

Histocompatibility haplotypes such as HLA-B1, HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, and HLA-DR4 are common in patients with autoimmune hepatitis.

Histopathological features include:

  • Plasma cell predominance in inflammatory infiltrates
  • Extensive interface hepatitis (piecemeal necrosis) 
  • Hepatocyte rosettes 

The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis showing characteristic lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and interface hepatitis.

Related Pearl: Types of autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)

  Type I AIH Type II AlH
Characteristic antibodies Anti-SMA (F-actin), ANA, pANCA, anti-SLA/LP, anti-AMA antibodies Anti-LKM1, anti-liver cytosol 1
Age of onset Bimodal, peaks at 10–20 years and 45–70 years 2–14 years
Gender distribution 78% female 89% female
lgG increase Pronounced Moderate
lgA decrease Absent Occasional
Association with HLA haplotypes B8, DR3, DR4 B14, DR3

Type III autoimmune hepatitis does not appear to represent a distinct category but, instead, is part of the spectrum of type I autoimmune hepatitis

  • ANA: Anti-nuclear antibodies
  • anti-SMA: Anti–smooth muscle actin antibodies
  • anti-SLA/LP: Anti–soluble liver antigen/liver–pancreas antigen
  • AMA: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies
  • anti-LKM: Liver–kidney microsomal antibodies
  • pANCA: Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

questions.text: Therapeutic index is calculated with which of the following equations?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic index is calculated with the following equation = LD50/ED50.

Therapeutic index is used to assess the safety of the drug administered.

LD50 (median lethal dose) refers to the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die. Larger the LD50, the safer the drug. In humans, TD50 is considered. TD50 refers to the dose of the drug that causes a toxic response in 50% of the population.

ED50 (median effective dose) refers to the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals show the specific or desired effect

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal necessary therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in patients with polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

JAK2 mutations can be found in the following neoplasms:

  • Polycythemia vera
  • Essential thrombocythemia
  • Primary myelofibrosis

 

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: An HIV positive patient presented to OPD with painless blurring of vision. On fundus examination, the following findings were seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Painless blurring of vision in an HIV positive patient with "sauce and cheese" or "pizza pie" retinopathy (shown in the image) is characteristic of cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

CMV retinitis is the most common ocular opportunistic infection in patients with HIV. It is often asymptomatic and can be classified as central or peripheral CMV retinitis. Central CMV retinitis is characterised by dense, white areas of retinal necrosis and retinal hemorrhage in the areas of necrosis - pizza pie or sauce and cheese appearance. 

Peripheral CMV retinitis is less demarcated. The infection spreads along the vascular arcades in a brush fire-like fashion.

questions.text: In a patient with acute compartment syndrome of the leg, which of the following muscles is most vulnerable to ischemia?
questions.solution:
Tibialis anterior is a muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg which is most commonly involved in compartment syndrome.

Anterior compartment muscles are more prone for ischemia because they have Type 1 fibers which depend on oxidative metabolism for their energy source, compared to type 2 fibers, whose metabolism is primarily anaerobic.

The three main compartments are anterior (extensor), lateral(fibular) and posterior (flexor). The posterior compartment is divided into deep and superficial parts by the transverse intermuscular septum.

The anterior compartment, the least expansile of the three, is bounded by the deep fascia, the interosseous surfaces of the tibia and fibula, the interosseous membrane and the anterior intermuscular septum

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV positive man presents with an acute onset high-grade fever with chills and shortness of breath. On evaluation, he's diagnosed to have a necrotising mediastinitis secondary to rupture of a retropharyngeal abscess. What is the likely route of spread of infection to the mediastinum?

choices.text: Between  buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia.
Between alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle

questions.solution:
The likely route of spread of infection is between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral fascia posteriorly. It is also called the danger space or alar space.

It lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. It extends from the skull base to the diaphragm. Infections from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger space.

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On examination, he notices the Kevorkian sign. What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
The Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels. It lasts for about 1 hour.

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea - dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to falling in intraocular pressure. IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous - linear increase up to 100 hours following death. It is helpful in determining the time since death

questions.text: An infraclavicular block was given in a patient with distal humerus fracture for open reduction and internal fixation. Which of the following branches of brachial plexus would likely be anesthetized?
questions.solution:
The thoracodorsal nerve would be anesthetized in the infraclavicular nerve block as it is an infraclavicular branch of the brachial plexus. It arises from the posterior cord (C6-C8).

Branches of the brachial plexus that arise from the roots and trunk are supraclavicular branches. They include:

  • Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)
  • Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
  • Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6)

All the other branches of the brachial plexus that arise from the cords are infraclavicular branches.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and discomfort for the past 2 months. She has been using oral contraceptive pills for more than 5 years. Imaging studies revealed a mass as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage is unlikely
Malignant transformation is seen in 10% of cases
Histology shows cords of hepatocytes with absence of bile ductules

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI showing homogeneous mass with well-defined margins is suggestive of hepatic adenoma. Rupture leading to life-threatening intraperitoneal hemorrhage is a major complication associated with hepatic adenomas.

Hepatic adenomas are benign solid neoplasms of the liver. They are usually seen in young women between 20-40 years of age and are typically solitary. Prolonged oral contraceptive use is a clear risk factor. Clinical presentation may be abdominal pain. 

Histological studies show cords of benign hepatocytes containing excessive glycogen and fat, giving a congested or vacuolated appearance. There is an absence of bile duct glands and Kupffer cells.

In some patients, hepatic adenomas present with spontaneous intraperitoneal hemorrhage. There is a risk of malignant transformation in 10% of cases.

The histopathological image given below shows hepatic adenoma.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument that is commonly used in a dilatation and curettage procedure.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Hegar's double-ended dilator which is used to dilate the cervix in dilation and curettage procedure. 

Pratt dilator is also a double-ended dilator but has a more linear shape as compared to the curved Hegar's dilators. The image given below shows a Pratt dilator.

 

Option A: Hawkin dilator is a single-ended dilator. The image given below shows a Hawkin dilator.

 

Option C: Bakes rosebud dilator is a single-ended dilator used to dilate the urethra. It is called so since its tip is similar to a rosebud. The image given below shows a Bakes dilator.

 

Option D: Fenton dilator is also double-ended but it has a notch in the middle. The image given below shows a Fenton dilator.

questions.text: An epidemiologist determines to evaluate the strength of association between asbestos exposure and mesothelioma in a case-control study. Which of the following variables would he use for it?
questions.solution:
Odds ratio (OR), also known as cross-product ratio, is used to measure the strength of association between risk factor (asbestos exposure) and outcome (mesothelioma) in case-control studies.

A case-control study yields only odds ratio and not incidence or relative risk.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: A woman with menorrhagia is diagnosed with uterine fibroids. Prior to starting treatment, you want to check if she is premenopausal. On which day of the menstrual cycle will you estimate her FSH levels?

choices.text: On day 2-5 after last menstrual period
On day 11-14 after last menstrual period

questions.solution:
The follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) level is studied on day 2–5 after the last menstrual period to detect the premenopausal stage.

It is a period of 3–4 years before menopause and is associated with mild ovarian hormonal deficiency leading to menstrual disorders, especially menorrhagia.

The climacteric phase is the phase of waning of ovarian activity. It begins 2 to 3 years before menopause and may continue 2-5 years after menopause. It marks the transition from active to inactive ovarian function and involves physical, sexual, and psychological adjustments.

The predictors of approaching menopause include:

  • A fall in the level of inhibin B and a corresponding rise in FSH level
  • A fall in the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) - This is a better marker of ovarian reserve and can be tested on any day of the cycle.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Sporangiophore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.

Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:

Class Sexual spore Asexual spore
Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospores Sporangiospores
Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia
Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia
Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes) Yet to be identified Conidia

Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.

Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the clinic with a high fever, cough, red eyes, and rash. The child's parents say that the rash started on the forehead and behind the ears, then subsequently spread to the neck and body. On examination, a confluent maculopapular rash is noted as shown below. Which of the following is false regarding this child's condition?

choices.text: The period of infectivity is 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash
The most common complication is pneumonia

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of measles. The most common complication of measles is acute otitis media. The most common cause of death is pneumonia (Hecht's giant cell pneumonia).

Measles (rubeola) is caused by RNA paramyxovirus. The infection is spread via droplets, with a secondary attack rate ≥of 90%. The patients are infectious from 4 days before upto 5 days after the appearance of the rash. The rash appears on the 4th day of fever. It starts from the retro auricular region. Koplik spots are pathognomonic.

The most common cause of death is pneumonia. Measles can lead to subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) as a late complication.

Measles can be prevented by administering live attenuated, Edmonston–Zagreb strain or combined MMR given at 9 months of age.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of papilledema?
questions.solution:
Disruption of neurofilaments is not a feature of papilledema.

Papilledema is the swelling of the optic nerve head secondary to raised intracranial pressure (ICP).

"Disc swelling" and "disc edema" are non-specific terms that include papilledema but also indicate a disc swollen from other causes.

All patients with papilledema should be suspected of harboring an intracranial mass.

Features of papilledema:

  • Raised ICP
  • Edema of the optic nerve head
    • Blockage of axoplasmic flow
    • Axonal swelling
    • Collection of extracellular fluid
  • Painless progressive loss of vision
  • Enlargement of the blind spot
  • Color vision, visual acuity, and pupillary reaction are normal, until optic atrophy sets in.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can cause green-colored urine in a patient?
questions.solution:
Green urine can be caused by triamterene, a potassium-sparing diuretic.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of chest pain and collapsed. He was taken to the hospital but was declared brought dead.  The condition responsible for the death of the patient is grouped under which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden cardiac death in a previously healthy man, under a stressful situation, is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. During extreme psychological stress, there is a catecholamine surge. This causes microcirculation spasms which lead to a transient myocardial stunning. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. 

It leads to left ventricular contractile dysfunction. The left ventricular apex is most often affected which leads to apical ballooning. This resembles a “takotsubo,” which is Japanese for “fishing pot for trapping octopus”.

Histologically, acute cases may show microscopic areas of necrosis characterized by myocyte hyper contraction known as contraction band necrosis. Chronic cases may exhibit microscopic foci of granulation tissue. 

The first image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The second image shows a 'takotsubo,' or octopus fishing pot.

questions.text: Identify the following graphical representation.
questions.solution:
The image shown above is a scatter diagram or scattergram.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent palpitation and lightheadedness. An ECG was taken and is as shown below. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows the presence of delta waves (preexcitation wave), wide QRS, and short PR interval which are classically seen in Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome. In this patient, catheter ablation is the best for long-term management. 

Patients with preexcitation who have symptoms of arrhythmia are at risk for developing AF and sudden death if they have an accessory pathway that allows rapid antegrade conduction (preexcitation & tachyarrhythmias are features of WPW syndrome due to the abnormal accessory pathway).

Complications of catheter ablation are rare but include AV block, cardiac tamponade, thromboembolic events, and hematoma at the access site.

Related Pearl: Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome

Wolff Parkinson White Syndrome (WPW) is characterized by an abnormal accessory pathway in the heart leading to arrhythmias.

Pathology- Born with an accessory pathway, the bundle of Kent which connects the atria and ventricle. The electrical impulses from the SA node reach the ventricles earlier via the accessory pathway as there is no AV nodal delay in this pathway. This leads to the preexcitation of the ventricle and initiation of ventricular contraction. This ventricular contraction is prolonged when the impulse via the AV nodal pathway reaches the ventricles.

Most common location of the accessory pathway- between the left atrium and free wall of the left ventricle

ECG changes:

Shortened PR interval- because of the early initiation of ventricular depolarization

Prolonged QRS duration- because of the AV nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

Delta waves- slurred upstroke of QRS complex

The given ECG shows delta waves marked with red arrows:

Treatment:

  • Catheter ablation is the treatment of choice.
  • Anti-arrhythmic drugs like procainamide, amiodarone, quinidine, propafenone, dofetilide are used in slowing conduction in the accessory pathway (prolong refractory period).
  • IV procainamide is the drug of choice in a hemodynamically stable WPW presenting with atrial fibrillation.
  • DC cardioversion is done in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Which of the toxins produced by clostridium species is the basis of Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
α-toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens forms the basis of Nagler's reaction.

The α-toxin of C.perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C.perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about Thymine?

choices.text: Can participate in hydrophobic interactions due to its methyl group
Is replaced by uracil in RNA
Normally forms two hydrogen bonds with adenine

questions.solution:
All of the following are true about thymine.

Thymine can participate in hydrophobic interactions due to its methyl group at 5th carbon.

Thymine is replaced by uracil in RNA.

Thymine forms two hydrogen bonds with adenine.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

Vernal conjunctivitis is also called spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis. It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years. It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of the conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC - Cobblestone papillae are present in the upper tarsal conjunctiva associated with ropy discharge. Maxwell–Lyon sign is present which is a pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC - Horner – Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

The image given below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

Treatment of this condition is with topical steroids and mast cell stabilizers such as cromolyn sodium. Topical cyclosporine can be used in patients who do not respond to first line treatment modalities.

questions.text: Half-life of T4_____
questions.solution:
The half-life of T4 is 6 - 7 days.

T3 has the shorter half-life of 1 day.

questions.text: A 2 week-old neonate developed meningitis following a scalp abscess. What is the likely route of spread?
questions.solution:
The infection has likely spread from the sub-aponeurotic tissue. 

The sub-aponeurotic loose areolar tissue of the scalp is referred to as the dangerous area of the scalp. Infection from this layer can pass into the cranial cavity through small emissary veins, which pass through parietal foramina in the calvaria. It can reach intracranial structures causing meningitis and intracranial abscesses. 

The scalp is a soft tissue that covers the calvaria of the skull. It consists of 5 layers as shown in the image below (mnemonic - SCALP):

questions.text: Identify the type of muscle marked as X in the image below.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked X in the cadaveric image is the pectoralis major, which is a spiral muscle. 

Spiral muscles have fiber architecture as follows:

  • The muscle fibers have a spiral or twisted arrangement. e.g., pectoralis major (sternocostal fibers) and latissimus dorsi that undergo a 180° twist between their medial and lateral attachments.
  • The entire muscle takes a spiral course around a bone. e.g., supinator winds obliquely around the proximal radial shaft.

Cruciate is a type of spiral muscle where two or more planes of muscle fibers are arranged in differing directions. e.g., sternocleidomastoid, masseter and adductor magnus are all partially spiral and cruciate.

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, 

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator and Trapezius

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: A child presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled by an array of drugs. Electroencephalogram (EEG) shows 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves with polyspike bursts in sleep. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with features of developmental delay, intractable seizures and an electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep has a likely diagnosis of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome.

Lennox–Gastaut syndrome- Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years. Consists of a triad of:

  • Developmental delay
  • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
  • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness

Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies. The drug of choice for Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is valproate. Other drugs used for this condition are clobazam, lamotrigine, rufinamide and topiramate.

Other options:

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome)- Typically, it starts in early adolescence (not in childhood) and the EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges

Landau–Kleffner syndrome- A rare condition characterized by loss of language skills in a previously normal child (not a child with developmental delay)

West syndrome- Starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and typical EEG picture is called hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage, slow with chaotic background)

Disease Typical EEG features Drug of choice
Lennox–Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep Valproate 
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern) Ethosuximide
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike polyspike and slow-wave discharges Valproate 
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

questions.text: Which drug produces phase II block?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine) produces both phases I and II blocks.

Suxamethonium is a depolarizing muscle relaxant.

Mechanism of depolarizing blockade:

  • Phase I block - continuous endplate depolarization and subsequent muscle relaxation.
  • Phase II block - seen with a single, large dose, repeated doses, or a continuous infusion which can lead to desensitization of the receptors resulting in the prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

Phase II block has features of a non-depolarizing blockade. But 'phase II' is specifically used for depolarizing blockade by succinylcholine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Life expectancy is a positive mortality indicator. 

A set of values that measure the rate of mortality or death is known as mortality indicators.

Disability-adjusted life years (DALY), health adjusted life expectancy (HALE), and Sullivan’s Index are disability rates.  

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding chlorination of water?

choices.text: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
Chlorine acts best when the  pH of water is around seven
It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for its disinfectant activity

questions.solution:
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around seven because of the predominance of the hypochlorous acid. Most water sources have a pH  around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective form of disinfection.

Option A: Orthotolidine test measures both free and combined chlorine in water.

Option C: Chlorination kills pathogenic bacteria, but has no effect on spores and certain viruses.

Option D: The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant was brought to the OPD by his mother with a history of passing watery stools more than 4 times in the past day. On examination, the baby is alert and on pinching his skin, it goes back quickly. The infant weighs 5.7 Kg. What is the initial fluid of choice for treating diarrhoea in this infant?
questions.solution:
In an infant with diarrhoea, the initial fluid of choice is oral rehydration solution (ORS).

The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag.

Studies have shown that low osmolarity ORS causes reduction of stool output, decrease in vomiting and decrease in the use of unscheduled intravenous fluids without increasing the risk of hyponatremia. Other home available fluids that can be used are salted rice water/salted yoghurt drinks, vegetable/chicken soup with salt.

ReSoMal is given to severely malnourished children. In this case, since the infant’s weight is appropriate for its age ORS is given.

Related Pearl: Composition of reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)

The composition of reduced-osmolarity oral rehydration solution (ORS) is as follows:

Reduced- osmolarity ORS mmol/L
Sodium  75 
Chloride 65
Glucose (anhydrous) 75
Potassium 20
Citrate 10
Total Osmolarity 245

questions.text: A patient is referred for the evaluation of severe right-sided abdominal pain. Abdominal X-ray appears normal, and a USG revealed the presence of a 6mm renal stone. Which of the following stones is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario since the stone is radiolucent, it is most likely to be uric acid stone.

Uric acid stones are preferentially formed in acidic urine. It is commonly associated with disorders of purine metabolism such as gout, and tumor lysis syndrome. On microscopic examination, the crystals appear as glass shards.

Patients with recurrent uric acid stones are treated with Allopurinol.

Note: 90% of the renal stones are radio-opaque, while 80% of gall bladder stones are radiolucent.

Related Pearl: Radiolucent Renal Stones

Radiolucent Renal Stones

Mnemonic: X UTI

  • Xanthine
  • Uric Acid (most common)

Drug induced renal stones

  • Triamterene
  • Indinavir

questions.text: A mother reports to you that her baby is irritable and cries all the time. She has also noticed that her infant sweats excessively while feeding. Which of the following findings noted during the examination would you not include under NADA's major criteria?

choices.text: Grade 2 mid-diastolic murmur at the mitral area
Grade 3 pansystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border

questions.solution:
Wide and variable S2 (Abnormal S2) is not included under Nada's major criteria.

Features of congestive cardiac failure, a grade 3 pansystolic murmur with wide and variable S2, and an MDM at the mitral area suggest a diagnosis of large VSD in this baby.

NADA's criteria for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease:

Major criteria  Minor criteria
Systolic murmur  grade 3 or more Systolic murmur < grade 3
Any diastolic murmur Abnormal second sound (S2)
Cyanosis Abnormal ECG
Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal chest X-ray findings
 

Abnormal BP

The presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria indicates congenital heart disease.

Pansystolic murmurs are always pathological no matter their intensity.

Short, soft systolic murmurs of intensity <3 are often detected during febrile illnesses, after which they disappear. Such murmurs are called innocent murmurs. Before labeling any murmur as innocent, it should be reassessed after an interval.

questions.text: Which among the following is the mainstay of treatment in a patient diagnosed with Stage III endometrial cancer?
questions.solution:
Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment in Stage III endometrial cancer.

In order to stage carcinoma endometrium, total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and lymphadenectomy is done (surgical staging). 

Thus the management, once staging is done, is mainly postoperative. Up to stage II, radiotherapy can be given. Stages III & IV are managed by chemotherapy such as doxorubicin, cisplatin, and paclitaxel.

Note: Stage III is said to be inoperable but debulking surgery is sometimes attempted. However, the mainstay of treatment for stage III disease remains chemotherapy.

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant

  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: An immunologist is conducting an experiment to understand precipitation reactions. He notes that on adding excessive amount of antigen to a serum sample containing small amount of antibodies, the amount of precipitate formed is less, compared to adding smaller amount of antigen to the same sample. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
This phenomenon is called post–zone phenomenon because it has excessive antigen in the test system, leading to weak or even absent precipitation. 

Lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.

  • Prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation- false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence- antigen, and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post–zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation) 

 

Flocculation: Instead of sedimenting, precipitate remains suspended as floculus.

questions.text: While examining a chronic alcoholic patient, you notice the given finding. Which of the following is false regarding it?

choices.text: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
Presence of even 1 lesion is abnormal
Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release

questions.solution:
The given image shows spider telangiectasia and the presence of >2 to 3 of these are considered abnormal.

Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in liver cirrhosis.

Clinical features seen in cirrhosis include:

  • Spider telangiectasias
  • Palmar erythema
  • Terry's nails - pallor of the proximal nail bed
  • Clubbing
  • Gynaecomastia
  • Caput medusae - dilated abdominal veins.
  • Parotid enlargement

The image below shows Terry's nails.

questions.text: Blood pressure is measured in an individual 5 times a day under the same conditions by a new screening test. All 5 readings obtained are the almost same. What is the attribute of a new screening test being described?
questions.solution:
The attribute of a new screening test to yield the same reading when repeated under the same conditions is called reliability.

Reliability is also called precision or reproducibility.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: A terrified computer engineer presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and inability to move for a few seconds after waking in the morning. He has a recurring hallucination of being suffocated by a great hound just as he falls asleep, which further disturbs him. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has sleep paralysis, excessive daytime sleepiness, and hypnagogic hallucinations, suggestive of narcolepsy. The drug of choice for narcolepsy is modafinil, an a1-adrenergic receptor agonist, used to reduce the number of sleep attacks and to improve psychomotor performance in narcolepsy.

Narcolepsy is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency.

Treatment: 

  • Sleep hygiene
  • Scheduled naps
  • Avoidance of alcohol and drugs that cause drowsiness
  • Drugs: 
    • Modafinil (wakefulness-promoting drug) is the drug of choice.
    • Amphetamines
    • Methylphenidate

The FDA recently approved an oral solution containing calcium, magnesium, potassium, and sodium oxybate to treat cataplexy or excessive daytime sleepiness who are ≥7years of age in patients with narcolepsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the muscle inserted to the area marked below?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman came with complaints of dull aching pain in the throat and right side of the face. She also frequently gets pain while swallowing associated with earache and headaches. On CT scan, a calcified stylohyoid ligament was seen. This ligament is derived from:
questions.solution:
The stylohyoid ligament is derived from the cartilage of the second pharyngeal arch which is Reichert's cartilage. 

Reichert's cartilage contributes to the development of the following structures:

The dorsal portion forms:

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process of the temporal bone
  • Stylohyoid ligament 

The ventral portion forms:

  • The upper part of the body and the lesser cornu of the hyoid bone.

Note: This condition is called Eagle syndrome. It is a condition associated with the elongation of the styloid process or calcification of the stylohyoid ligament.

These structures can be remembered as 5S's:

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process of the temporal bone
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Smaller (lesser) cornu of the hyoid bone
  • Superior part of the body of the hyoid bone

questions.text: Consider the following statements about multiple myeloma and identify the incorrect statement.

choices.text: 5th–7th decade is the common presenting age
IL-5 is the most important interleukin in the pathogenesis of multiple myeloma
Translocation of the gene coding for cyclin D1 is responsible for the development of abnormal immunoglobulins
Spine is the most common site for multiple myeloma

questions.solution:
• IL-6 is the most important interleukin required for the proliferation and survival of plasma cells, and hence, it is an important interleukin in the pathogenesis of multiple myeloma.
  • Translocation in the IgH locus, genes, cyclin D1, cyclin D3, deletion of chromosome 17p are responsible for the development of abnormal immunoglobulins.
  • Spine is the most common site for multiple myeloma followed by ribs, skull, and pelvis.

questions.text: Which organism causes the disease shown below?
questions.solution:
The image showed a rash on the cheeks and face - a slapped cheek appearance - characteristic of erythema infectiosum/ fifth disease. It is caused by parvovirus B19.

Parvovirus B19 is a DNA virus affecting immature RBC progenitors. It most commonly causes erythema infectiosum. Children present with low-grade fever, mild upper respiratory symptoms and an erythematous maculopapular rash. The rash starts as prominent erythema of the cheek - slapped-cheek appearance. The rash further spreads to the trunk and limbs followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia. Later, there is central clearing of the macular lesions of the rash, leading to a lacy, reticulated pattern.

Parvovirus B19 induces aplastic crisis in sickle cell anemia patients. Infection during pregnancy leads to non-immune fetal hydrops (highest risk in the first half of gestational period).

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the dermatologist by her parents. She has many freckles on her face and limbs as shown below. She is also unusually sensitive to sunlight. Early changes of squamous cell carcinomas are also noted on her face. Which of the following processes is most like to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Photosensitivity, freckling and skin cancer on the face in a child aare suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair. 

In xeroderma pigmentosum, there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure. It is an autosomal recessive disease characterized by exaggerated sunburns and pigmentary changes on exposure to UV radiations. There is increased risk of developing non-melanoma and melanoma skin cancers, and neurodegeneration. They are also more prone to developing smoking-induced lung cancers. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical and it can be confirmed definitively by cellular tests for defective DNA repair. Management includes sun avoidance and regular follow-up to assess and treat any skin cancers. There is no cure for xeroderma pigmentosum.

questions.text: What is the effect of cholecystokinin on GIT?
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin (CCK) inhibits gastric emptying. 

It is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, fatty acids, and amino acids.

Primary functions:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • Contraction of the gallbladder
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

Other functions:

  • Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline (bicarbonate rich) pancreatic juice
  • Inhibition of gastric emptying
  • Trophic (growth) effect on the exocrine pancreas
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon
  • Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing the reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach
  • It promotes satiety

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the clinical triad of Sézary syndrome?

choices.text: Atypical mononuclear cells > 20% of total lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Seborrhoeic keratosis is not a part of the clinical triad of Sézary syndrome 

The clinical triad of Sézary syndrome consists of the following:

  1. Erythroderma - As a result of diffuse infiltration of the skin by neoplastic cells 
  2. Peripheral lymphadenopathy
  3. Atypical mononuclear cells (Sézary cells) comprising more than 20% of total lymphocyte count or total Sézary count of more than 1000 × 109/L

questions.text: The accumulation of aggregates of the protein ______ is associated with Parkinson disease and multiple system atrophy.
questions.solution:
The pathologic process that is common across most of the neurodegenerative diseases is the accumulation of protein aggregates, which is a morphologic hallmark of the disease.

The protein aggregates are recognized histologically as inclusions, which often are the diagnostic hallmark of the disease.

The basis for aggregation varies from one disease to another.

It may be directly related to an intrinsic feature of a mutated protein (e.g., expanded polyglutamine repeats in Huntington disease), an intrinsic feature of a peptide derived from a larger precursor protein (e.g., Aβ in Alzheimer disease), or an unexplained alteration of a normal cellular protein (e.g., α-synuclein in sporadic Parkinson disease).

questions.text: Which of the following is not an IVP finding in patients with renal papillary necrosis?
questions.solution:
The ball on tee sign is seen in renal papillary necrosis, not ball and socket. 

Renal papillary necrosis refers to ischemic necrosis of the renal papillae. It can be acute or chronic. Calyceal or ureteral obstruction by sloughed papillae manifests with flank pain, haematuria, and renal impairment. The common causes include analgesic abuse (phenacetin, NSAIDs, paracetamol: especially in combination), diabetes mellitus, sickle cell disease, pyelonephritis (especially in children) and obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells?
questions.solution:
Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells.

Naive CD4+ T cells are activated when they come in contact with two ligands - MHC class II and a costimulary membrane protein (eg: CD28). Both of these are present in antigen-presenting cells, the most potent of which is the mature dendritic cell. Other professional antigen-presenting cells include macrophages and B lymphocytes (option C).

Other options:

Option B: Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

Option D: NK cells do not stimulate naive T cells.

questions.text: Ricinoleic acid is the active agent for which of the following stimulant laxatives?
questions.solution: Castor oil is derived from bean of the castor plant Ricinus communis. The oil is mainly made of triglyceride of ricinoleic acid. In small bowel, oil is hydrolyzed to release glycerides and ricinoleic acid which is the active agent. It primarily acts on the small intestine to stimulate secretion of fluid and electrolytes and speed intestinal transit.

questions.text: In a child with obesity, hypogonadism, and mental retardation, which of the following would you not suspect ?
questions.solution:
Children with Angelman syndrome present with mental retardation but do not have obesity and hypogonadism. It occurs due to the deletion of band q12 of the maternal chromosome 15.

The following syndromes present with obesity, hypogonadism, and mental retardation

  • Prader-Willi syndrome - deletion of band q12 of the paternal chromosome 15.
  • Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome
  • Carpenter syndrome
  • Cohen syndrome

The following image shows a child with Prader-Willi syndrome.

questions.text: Mr. and Mrs. A believed that a 'demon' told Mr. A that they would be killed imminently, so the couple bought a gun to protect themselves. While eating at a restaurant, they perceived two male diners to be laughing at them. They believed that the demon was urging them to kill the diners, and they shot the two men dead. While defending the couple in court, their lawyer mentioned a psychiatric disorder. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of folie à deux. It is also known as shared delusional disorder, shared psychotic disorder, or induced psychotic disorder.

In this syndrome, two individuals with a close and generally long-term relationship share the same delusional belief. Persecutory delusional beliefs are most commonly seen in this disorder.

Occasionally, more than two individuals are involved ( e.g., folie á trois, quatre, cinq; also folie á famille), but such cases are especially rare.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with pain in the right wrist following a fall on the outstretched hand. On examination, tenderness was noted in the anatomical snuff box. Radiograph of her wrist is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and radiograph showing a large gap between the scaphoid and lunate are suggestive of scapholunate dissociation. 

It is also known as tooth gap sign or Terry Thomas sign, after the English comedian.
