questions.text: You have performed MTP on a multigravida at 10 weeks of gestation.  As a part of post-op advice, you must prescribe her a prophylactic antibiotic. Which of the following drugs would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is the preferred drug for post-abortal antibiotic prophylaxis in this case. Oral doxycycline 100 mg is given 1 hour before surgical evacuation. 200 mg is given after the procedure is complete.

The best method of MTP at 7-12 weeks is by suction and evacuation. Following this procedure, antibiotic prophylaxis is given with doxycycline.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?
  1. Cervical tear is the most common cause of traumatic PPH
  2. The vulva is the most common site for pelvic hematoma
  3. The pudendal artery is the most common artery involved in vulval hematoma
  4. Hematomas of >3cm must be surgically explored under general anesthesia
  5. Lower uterine segment rupture causes infra-levator hematoma
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 3 are true.

Statement 4: Hematomas <5 cm can be managed conservatively with cold compress. Larger hematomas need to be explored surgically. 

Statement 5: Lower uterine segment rupture causes supra-levator hematoma.

Types of pelvic hematomas:

Feature Infralevator hematoma Supralevator hematoma
Incidence Common Rare
Location Below the levator ani Above the levator ani
Causes Improper hemostasis during repair of vaginal/ perineal tears or episiotomy wound Extension of cervical laceration, lower uterine segment rupture
Presentation Severe pain with rectal tenesmus Unexplained shock with features of internal haemorrhage
Treatment Small hematomas can be conservatively managed with cold compress Laparotomy

questions.text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.

It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 

Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.

Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to fusion of vertebral bodies.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs of Hyperparathyroidism

Rugger jersey spine: It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey.

Subperiosteal bone resorption: This is seen on the radial side of the proximal and middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers. It is the most consistent and specific finding of hyperparathyroidism and is virtually pathognomonic of the condition.

Brown tumors / Osteitis fribrosa cystica / Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone: These are composed of pseudotumors that are made up of macrophages, blood, and connective tissue. They are seen as radiolytic areas due to the reduction in the bone trabeculae.                        

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull:  Refers to multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the calvaria of the skull ( top part of the skull) due to resorption of the trabecular bone. Alternate areas of mineralization (salt-white) and decalcification (pepper-black)

Acral osteolysis: This is also known as the tufting of phalanges

questions.text: The most frequent fracture site due to osteoporosis induced by glucocorticoids is_____.
questions.solution:
• Glucocorticoids preferentially affect trabecular bone and the cortical rim of vertebral bones.
  • Ribs and vertebra are the most frequent sites of fracture with glucocorticoids-induced osteoporosis.

questions.text: Specific dynamic action is maximum for ______
questions.solution:
Specific dynamic action is maximum for proteins.

Specific dynamic action/diet-induced thermogenesis/ thermic effect of food is the extra energy needed by the body for digestion, absorption, and disposal of ingested nutrients.

Specific dynamic action magnitude depends on the composition of the food consumed:

  • Carbohydrates: 5 to 15% of the energy consumed
  • Fats: at most 5 to 15 %
  • Protein: 20 to 35% 

The energy generated by the metabolism of the macronutrients is used for three energy-requiring processes that occur in the body:

  • Resting metabolic rate
  • Thermic effect of food (formerly termed specific dynamic action)
  • Physical activity

questions.text: The intrapleural pressure (cm of H2O)  at the beginning of inspiration is around
questions.solution:
The normal intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration is about -3.4 cm H2O (-2.5 mmHg).

Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the lung pleura and the chest wall pleura. During normal inspiration, expansion of the chest cage pulls outward on the lungs with greater force and creates more negative pressure.

At the peak of normal inspiration, it is about -8.15 cm H2O (-5.4 mm Hg).

Note: 1mm Hg = 1.36 cm H2O

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm).

The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter  and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presented with poor growth and social interaction as well as midline stereotypical movements of the hands as seen in the image below. All milestones were normal for the first 2 years. After that, the milestones delayed and her development slowed down. On examination, her gait was slightly clumsy, her speech had regressed to mere babbling and her anthropometry was below the 50th percentile. Following a battery of investigations, the diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. What is the affected gene for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given features of poor growth & social interaction, gradual loss of speech, clumsy gait along with the characteristic hand movements point towards a likely diagnosis of Rett’s syndrome. The gene involved in Rett’s syndrome is the MeCP2 gene located on the X chromosome (Xq28 predominantly of paternal origin). 

Rett’s syndrome:

  • Almost always affects girls (X- linked dominant)
  • Development may proceed normally until 1 year of age slowing down to the extent of regression. 
  • After 1 year of age, rapid regression in language and hand skills, motor milestones, and acquired microcephaly become apparent.
  • Clinical features can include repetitive hand wringing movements, ataxia, breathing dysfunction, bruxism, scoliosis, and profound mental retardation.
  • Autistic behaviour is a typical finding in all patients.

Note:

  • Rb: Retinoblastoma: 13 chromosome
  • P53: Li–Fraumeni syndrome, Sarcomas: 17
  • NF1: Neurofibromatosis 1-17
  • NF2: Neurofibromatosis 2-22
  • WT1: Wilms's tumour: 11
  • FGFR3: Achondroplasia

questions.text: Idarucizumab is a reversal agent for
questions.solution:
Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to dabigatran and its acylglucuronide metabolites with higher affinity than the binding affinity of dabigatran to thrombin.

Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants:

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency with symptoms of unstable angina. ECG done in pain-free interval showed biphasic T waves in precordial leads without ST changes. Cardiac troponins were normal. Coronary angiography revealed stenosis of the proximal left anterior descending artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of Wellens syndrome. It is alternatively known as anterior, descending, T-wave syndrome. The ECG pattern of Wellens syndrome is relatively common in patients who exhibit symptoms consistent with unstable angina. 

ECG in the pain-free interval is characterized by deeply inverted or biphasic T waves in precordial leads and with minimal or no ST elevations. Cardiac enzymes are normal or mildly elevated.

These patients are at high risk for impending large anterior wall acute myocardial infarction.

The ECG below shows biphasic T waves in leads V2 and V3 and inverted T waves in leads V4 and V5 in Wellens syndrome. 

Option A: Broken heart syndrome is another name for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

Option C: Barlow syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse.

Option D: Brugada syndrome is a genetic cardiac rhythm disorder.

questions.text: What does Billing's method of contraception refer to?
questions.solution:
Billing’s method of contraception refers to the cervical mucus method. It is also called ovulation method.

The properties of the cervical mucus change during the menstrual cycle. The female partner can predict the fertile period by examining her cervical mucus.

Under the influence of estrogen, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes more slippery and elastic i.e. wet days. This continues till it reaches a peak. After this, under the influence of progesterone, it becomes thicker, scanty i.e. dry days.

Abstinence is advised during the wet days till 4 days after the peak day. The safe period includes the dry days after menses till the appearance of mucus and from the 4th day after the peak day. 

The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below.

questions.text: All the following are posterior relations of the head of the pancreas except:
questions.solution:
Transverse mesocolon is an anterior relation of the head of the pancreas

Relations of the head of pancreas:

  • Anterior:
    • 1st part of duodenum
    • Origin of the transverse mesocolon
  • Posterior:
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Common bile duct (which is embedded in the head)
    • Right crus of diaphragm
    • Termination of the right gonadal vein
    • Right renal vein
    • Right renal artery

Relations of the neck of pancreas:

  • Anterior
    • pylorus
    • The anterior superior pancreaticoduodenal branch of the gastroduodenal artery
  • Posterior
    • Portal vein
    • Superior mesenteric vein
    • Inferior mesenteric (in 1/3rd individuals)

 

Clinical note: Cancers arising from the head or neck of the pancreas are difficult to operate on due to the confluence of so many vessels near them. This also makes blood-borne spread faster.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of cough and fever. Chest X-ray shows obliteration of the right cardiac border. Which anatomical site is likely involved in the pathology?
questions.solution:
Obliteration of the right cardiac border on chest X-ray indicates pathology in the right middle lobe.

This loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures (heart, diaphragm) is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air. This sign may be seen in consolidation, atelectasis, or mass lesions.

In the following images:

  • Left image - red line indicates the normal demarcation between the right heart border and middle lobe of the right lung
  • Right image - loss of demarcation (positive silhouette sign) due to right middle lobe consolidation

Positive silhouette sign and corresponding anatomical site of pathology:

  • Right heart border - right middle lobe or medial right lower lobe
  • Left heart border - lingula segments of the left upper lobe
  • Left hemidiaphragm or descending aorta - left lower lobe
  • Aortic knuckle - left upper lobe (posterior segment)
  • Right hemidiaphragm - right lower lobe
  • Right paratracheal stripe - right upper lobe

questions.text:
A 30-year-old albino woman presents with a characteristic finding as shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the suspected condition?
  1. It is due to the deposition of copper in the Descemet's membrane
  2. It requires screening for underlying lipid disorder
  3. It is seen in patients with the neurological form of Wilson’s disease
  4. If seen unilaterally it is suggestive of ipsilateral carotid stenosis
  5. It is also called limbus sign
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old individual with corneal changes, as shown above, known as gerontoxon or arcus lipoides, may require screening for underlying lipid disorder.

Arcus senilis (AS), also known as gerontoxon, arcus lipoides or arcus cornealis, is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral cornea that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity, typically benign, occurring bilaterally and prevalent among the elderly.

However, when observed in individuals under 50, termed arcus juvenilis, it may indicate underlying lipid disorder and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, warranting lipid profile screening. Unilateral cases of arcus senilis may indicate contralateral carotid artery stenosis due to decreased ophthalmic blood flow on the ipsilateral side, resulting in protection from forming arcus in the ipsilateral eye.

The condition results from the leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma, initiating deposition at the superior and inferior cornea. Over time, the ring progresses circumferentially, sparing a clear corneal zone adjacent to the limbus called the interval of Vogt.

The following opacities and rings can resemble arcus senilis:

  • Kayser- Fleischer (KF) ring: A dark brown ring caused by the deposition of excess copper in Descemet's membrane, classically seen in Wilson's disease. It may also be seen in certain chronic, cholestatic liver conditions such as primary biliary cirrhosis. 
  • Limbus sign: Caused by dystrophic calcification, seen as a "milky precipitate" at the corneal limbus. It can sometimes be confused with AS in the elderly population.
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon: A greyish peri-limbal band of superficial scarring adjacent to a previously inflamed segment of the limbus resembling AS, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

The image below depicts the Kayser–Fleischer ring and anterior capsule of the crystalline lens (Sunflower cataract) seen in Wilson's disease.

questions.text: An oncologist orders a bone scan to assess for bony metastases in a 49-year-old woman with breast cancer.  The radioactive isotope of which of the following is used?
questions.solution:
Technetium tagged to various substrates is used for bone scans.

The patient is injected with a small amount of radioactive material such as 600 MBq of technetium-99m-MDP and scanned with a gamma camera, a device sensitive to the radiation emitted by the injected material. MDP (methyl diphosphonate) adsorbs into the hydroxyapatite crystals and accumulates in the areas of active bone formation. 

Given below is a bone scan demonstrating bony metastasis in the pelvis.

Other options:

Phosphorous (P-32) and Iridium (Ir-192) are used in radiotherapy.

questions.text: Who was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848?
questions.solution:
Edwin Chadwick was the architect of the Public Health Act of 1848.

He was an English lawyer during the 1832 cholera epidemic. He compiled a report on the Sanitary Condition of the Labouring Population in Great Britain that eventually led to the passing of this act. It is considered a landmark act in the history of public health.

questions.text: A pregnant woman suffered a miscarriage at 6 months of gestation. What would be the expected crown heel length of this fetus?
questions.solution:
Crown heel length of a 6-month-old fetus would be 30 cm.

According to the rule of Hasse:

  • During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.
  • During last five months, the length in centimeters is divided by five gives the age in months.

So, crown heel length = age in months × 5 (i.e. 6 × 5 = 30 cm).

questions.text: Spread of disease via which of the following is an example of an indirect mode of transmission?
questions.solution:
The spread of a disease through contaminated food is an example of vehicle-borne transmission. It is an indirect mode of transmission.

Vehicle-borne transmission is the transmission of infectious agents through food, water and biological products (blood, plasma etc.). Of these, food and water are more frequent vehicles of transmission because they are used by everyone.

Mother to child transmission, droplet infection and transmission via dog bite are examples of direct modes of transmission.

questions.text: The new online RNTCP software launched by the government to monitor the TB control programme is called:
questions.solution:
Nikshay is a web-based solution for monitoring of TB patients.

Nikusth is the web-based solution for monitoring of Leprosy patients.

Nischay is a pregnancy test kit.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented to the ER with severe dehydration and weakness. History was suggestive of multiple episodes of watery diarrhea and non-bilious vomiting since morning. His breath reeked of garlic odor. ECG showed QT prolongation.  Which of the following samples must be collected for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of acute arsenic poisoning. For a definitive diagnosis, the arsenic levels are measured in 24-hour urine samples.

If the baseline urinary level is within normal limits and arsenic intoxication is still suspected, hair and nail clippings should be harvested for laboratory analysis. Due to the rapid distribution of arsenic in tissues, blood arsenic levels are unreliable.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

C- Cholera like illness

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: Mohit is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of red-eye. He complains of blurring of vision and on examination, the pupil appears as shown in the picture. Which of the following subtype of JIA is associated with the highest risk for the ophthalmic complication noted in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has red-eye and the blurring of vision along with the finding of the irregular pupil, which is suggestive of uveitis. ANA-positive oligoarthritis is associated with the highest risk for uveitis in patients with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.

The presence of a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination every 3 months.

questions.text:
All of the following statements are true regarding oogenesis except:

LH- Luteinizing hormone

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division
1st meiotic division of the secondary follicle resumes with LH surge

questions.solution:
The second statement i.e. that secondary oocytes arrest in metaphase of the first meiotic division is not true.

The secondary oocyte actually arrests in the metaphase of the second meiotic division. (Option C)

Other options-

Option (A): The primary oocyte arrests in the prophase of the 1st meiotic division (diplotene stage). These primary oocytes remain arrested in this manner until puberty. They become surrounded by a layer of flat epithelial cells and are then called primordial follicles.

Option (D): The 1st meiotic division of the secondary follicle resumes with the cyclical LH (luteinizing hormone) surge. This is the parameter required for ovulation to occur.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a thrombopoietin receptor agonist?
questions.solution:
Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analogue that stimulates megakaryocyte maturation and is not a thrombopoietin receptor agonist.

Romiplostim, eltrombopag and lusutrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists. They are indicated in patients with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) who have failed to respond to the conventional treatments.

questions.text: A catheter is inserted into the limb of a patient suspected to have compartment syndrome. What minimum reading on the pressure monitor will prompt an immediate fasciotomy?
questions.solution:
The pressure threshold for doing a fasciotomy in a case of suspected compartment syndrome is 30 mmHg

Fasciotomy involves incising the deep muscle fascia and is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, fat, and fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pathogenic mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Aedes and Anopheles lay eggs singly.

Culex lays eggs in rafts and Mansonia lays eggs in star-shaped clusters.

Anopheles has spotted wings while the other pathogenic species have unspotted wings.

Aedes transmits yellow fever, dengue and chikungunya. Culex is the main vector for JE and filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a glycolipid?
questions.solution:
Cerebroside is an example of a glycolipid.

A glycolipid is a complex lipid containing a carbohydrate. Cerebrosides consist of sphingosine, a fatty acid and a single sugar linked to sphingosine. Thus, they are glycolipids. Cerebrosides are found predominantly in the brain and peripheral nervous tissue, with high concentrations in the myelin sheath.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not increase the risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia vera increases the risk of developing AML, not ALL.

Inherited diseases that are associated with a higher risk of developing leukemias are:

  • Bloom syndrome
  • Fanconi anemia
  • Ataxia–telangiectasia
  • Down syndrome
  • Type-1 neurofibromatosis

Other germline risk factors for the development of ALL:

  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
  • Familial ALL syndrome

Note: AML has a higher incidence during the neonatal period than ALL among children with Fanconi anemia, Bloom syndrome, and Down syndrome.

questions.text: What is the normal value of y/x in the following representation?
questions.solution:
In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4. 

It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:

  • Hypersecretion of mucus
  • Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
  • Goblet-cell hyperplasia
  • Inflammation
Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis:

questions.text: McCallum’s patch is seen mostly in which chamber of the heart?
questions.solution:
In rheumatic heart disease, McCallum plaques are seen usually in the left atrium.

It is due to subendocardial lesions which may induce irregular thickenings.

Image- Thickened endocardium or McCallum's patch in a heart affected by rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: Ask-Upmark kidney refers to ________
questions.solution:
The Ask-Upmark kidney is also termed segmental hypoplasia.

Renal segmental hypoplasia:

  • Severe segmental renal atrophy with loss of parenchymal elements in small kidneys is commonly known as segmental hypoplasia.
  • It refers to small kidneys, usually weighing not more than 35 g.
  • The scars are seen as cortical depressions overlying shrunken medullary pyramids and their dilated calyces, and they are characterized histologically by colloid-filled tubular microcysts and a paucity or absence of glomeruli.
  • Most patients are 10 years or older at diagnosis and have severe hypertension.
  • Nephrectomy usually controls the hypertension.

questions.text: The following effect in the motor neuron is due to:

choices.text: Opening of chloride ion channels through the pre-synaptic neuronal membrane
Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the inside of the neuron
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors
Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron

questions.solution:
Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors can cause the effect shown, namely, the generation of IPSP.

In the figure given, there is an increased negativity in the motor neuron following the action potential in the interneuron. So, the synaptic potential is IPSP. This can be caused at the postsynaptic membrane due to Cl- influx, K+ efflux or activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors or decrease the number of excitatory receptors.

Other options:

  • Opening of chloride ion channels through the post-synaptic neuronal membrane. 
  • Increase in conductance of potassium ions to the outside of the postsynaptic neuron.
  • Increase in conductance of sodium ions inside the neuron causes the generation of an EPSP.

Related Pearl: Comparison between EPSP vs IPSP

EPSP IPSP
EPSP is an electrical charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of excitatory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane more likely to generate an action potential. IPSP is an electric charge on the postsynaptic membrane, which is caused by the binding of inhibitory neurotransmitters and makes the postsynaptic membrane less likely to generate an action potential.
EPSP is caused by Influx of Na+ or Ca2+ ions IPSP is caused by Influx of Cl- ions mainly (also by efflux of K+ ions)
Results in depolarization of membrane Results in hyperpolarization of membrane
Increases the firing rate of action potential on postsynaptic membrane Decreases the firing rate of action potential on post synaptic membrane
Neurotransmitters involved – Glutamate, Aspartate Neurotransmitters involved – Glycine, GABA

 

EPSP- Excitatory PostSynaptic Potentials

IPSP- Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potentials

questions.text: Mebendazole is not indicated for _______.
questions.solution:
Mebendazole is not indicated for onchocerciasis. 

It is treated with ivermectin as a single dose given every 6-12 months. Treatment of onchocerciasis with mebendazole may result in blindness due to reactions.

Mebendazole is indicated for use in Ascariasis, Enterobius vermicularis, and hydatid cyst disease (Options A, B and D).

questions.text: Deficiency of complement components C5-C8 leads to ______

choices.text: Recurrent infections with gram negative cocci
Recurrent swelling of the lips and tongue

questions.solution:
Deficiency of terminal complement components (C5-C8) leads to recurrent infections with gram negative cocci. 

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema. 
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other Collagen vascular disorders.
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Recurrent bacteremia with Neisseria. 
  • CD 59 deficiency - Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

Related Pearl: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

 

Complement protein Effects of deficiency
C1, C2, C4 Immune- complex disease (SLE)
C3, Factor I Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria
C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria
Factor D. properdin (factor P) Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria and Neisseria.

DAF (Decay accelerating factor)

CD 59

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C1-inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema

 

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: Non-lactating women should start using contraceptives in ______
questions.solution:
Non-lactating women should start using contraceptives in 3rd postpartum week. 

Lactating mother Non Lactating mother
Ovulation occurs after 10 weeks Ovulation occurs after 4 weeks
Use contraceptive in 3rd post-partum month Use contraceptive in 3rd post-partum week

Note:

Rule of 3's

  • Full breast feeding: contraception from 3rd postpartum month.
  • No/Partial feeding:contraception from 3rd postpartum week.

questions.text: The most common location of cystic hygroma is ________.
questions.solution:
Cystic hygroma, also known as cystic lymphangioma and macrocystic lymphatic malformation, is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that can arise anywhere but is classically found in the left posterior triangle of the neck.

The other common sites are the axillary, mediastinal, inguinal, and retroperitoneal regions. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. The cysts are lined by endothelium and filled with lymph.

The image below shows a newborn with cystic hygroma on the right side of the neck.

questions.text: All of the following enzymes are components of the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme complex, except
questions.solution:
Pyruvate kinase is not a component of the Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) enzyme complex.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to Acetyl-CoA.

The three enzyme components are:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

The Cofactors are:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is : Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Clinical aspects:

  • Arsenite and mercuric ions react with the -SH groups of lipoic acid and inhibit pyruvate dehydrogenase.
  • Dietary deficiency of thiamin inhibits PDH eg. Chronic alcoholics may develop potentially fatal pyruvic and lactic acidosis.
  • Patients with inherited pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency present with lactic acidosis, particularly after a glucose load and neurological disturbances.

Note : Pyruvate kinase catalyses the last step of glycolysis ie- transfering phosphate group from phosphoenol pyruvate to ADP forming pyruvate and ATP respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors recognize fungi?
questions.solution:
C-type lectin receptors (CLRs) detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

The various classes of innate immune receptors are as follows:

 Receptors Location Function
Toll-like receptors Plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles

Important TLRs and molecules recognised:

  • TLR2 - peptidoglycan of gram + bacteria, lipopolysaccharide of Leptospira
  • TLR3 - dsRNA viruses
  • TLR4Q - Chlamydia and lipopolysaccharide
NOD-like receptors Cytosol of immune cells and epithelial cells
  • Recognise substances from necrotic cells and microbial products
  • Signals via inflammasome which activates caspase and IL-1
C-type lectin receptors  Plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells
  • Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi
RIG-like receptors Cytosol of most cell types
  • Detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of infected cells
  • Stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines
  • Recognize short bacterial peptides containing N-formyl methionyl residues and stimulate chemotaxis
Mannose receptors Plasma membrane of macrophages, immature dendritic cells, and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells
  • Detect microbial sugars (which often contain terminal mannose residues) and induce phagocytosis of the microbes

Mannose receptor is a soluble pattern-recognition receptor. All the others are surface pattern-recognition receptors.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. On examination, you observe the following. He is diagnosed with herpangina. Which group of viruses causes the same?
questions.solution:
The given image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina. It is caused by the coxsackievirus A, a large subgroup of the enteroviruses.

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by grayish- white papulovesicular lesions on an erythematous base that ulcerate. These are present on:

  • Soft palate
  • Anterior pillars of tonsils
  • Uvula
  • Posterior oropharynx

It is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackievirus A infection in children, but it can also be caused by coxsackievirus B, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71.

Treatment is usually only supportive, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week.

questions.text: How is alteplase differentiated from streptokinase?

choices.text: It is derived from human kidney
It has more affinity towards plasminogen bound to fibrin

questions.solution:
Alteplase differs from streptokinase as it has more affinity towards plasminogen bound to fibrin.

It activates fibrin-bound plasminogen more rapidly than it activates plasminogen in the circulation. Streptokinase activates both free and fibrin bound plasminogen. 

Option A: Alteplase is rapidly cleared by the liver and inactivated by plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 making it shorter-acting than streptokinase.

Option B: It is also more expensive than streptokinase 

Option C: Alteplase is the recombinant tissue-type plasminogen activator derived from human tissue (endothelial cells) culture.

Related Pearl: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

  • Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Anistreplase
  • Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

  • Alteplase - has the shortest half-life
  • Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose
  • Reteplase

questions.text: You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in a patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. On workup, she has splenomegaly and her blood count showed neutropenia and lymphocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome. Some patients with Felty's syndrome have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlying cause.

Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a T-cell (CD3+) and NK-cell (CD56+) variant leukemia. They are associated with mutations in the transcription factor, STAT3.

Patients usually presents with mild to moderate lymphocytosis and splenomegaly. Neutropenia and anemia are also present. Lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly are usually absent. 

There is an increased incidence of rheumatological disorders associated with this condition.

The peripheral smear picture shows large lymphocytes with abundant blue cytoplasm and few azurophilic granules.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mental health?

choices.text: Mental disorders are universal, not specific to any group
Mental health is the mere absence of mental illness
Heredity can contribute to mental illnesses
Substance abuse is a type of mental illness

questions.solution:
Mental health is a state of well-being in which an individual realizes his or her own abilities and not merely the absence of mental illness. It is the ability to cope with stress, be productive, and contribute to the community. 

Mental disorders are universal and are not specific to any particular group. They are associated with hereditary (family history of psychiatric disorders) and environmental factors. Substance abuse and alcohol addiction are considered types of mental illness.

questions.text: Quarantine measures were implemented for the first time to prevent the spread of:
questions.solution:
Quarantine was introduced for the first time to prevent the spread of the plague, also known as the black death. 

Quarantine is the restriction on the movement of people, animals, and goods that may have been exposed to a communicable disease. It is intended to prevent the spread of communicable diseases. 

Quarantine is distinct from medical isolation, in which those confirmed to be infected with a communicable disease are isolated from the healthy population.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle is India in currently?
questions.solution:
Currently, India is in stage 3 i.e. late expanding stage of the demographic cycle.

Note: The year 1921 is called the year of the great divide in India. This is because, since 1921, the absolute number of people getting added to the population during each decade has been on the rise. This is the year in which India moved from stage 2 to stage 3 of the demographic cycle.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: All of the following are features of parietal lobe lesion except ____
questions.solution:
Urinary incontinence is not a feature of parietal lobe lesion.  

Urinary incontinence is a feature of frontal lobe lesion.

The features of parietal lobe lesions are as follows:

  • Apraxia
  • Acalculia
  • Alexia
  • Agnosia
  • Neglect
  • Inferior quadrantic homonymous hemianopia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Rotterdam criteria used to diagnose?
questions.solution:
The Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose Stein-Levinthal syndrome or PCOS. 

ESHRE/ASRM or Rotterdam criteria (2003):

Any two out of these three must be present-

  • Clinical/ Biochemical hyperandrogenism
  • Oligo/anovulation
  • Polycystic ovaries

Other criteria used for diagnosing PCOS:

  • National Institute of Health (NIH) criteria (1990)
    • To include both
      • Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism
      • Oligo/anovulation
  • Androgen excess and PCOS society(AE-PCOS) criteria:
    • To include both:
      • Clinical/Biochemicalhyperandrogenism
      • Oligo/anovulation/polycystic ovaries

Option A: Meig's syndrome refers to ascites and pleural effusions that accompany a benign ovarian tumor.

Option B: Asherman's syndrome refers to the formation of intrauterine synechiae, usually following endometrial destructive procedures like curettage or ablation.

Option C: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome is characterised by congenital absence of vagina, primary amenorrhoea, rudimentary cornua uteri and morphologically normal ovaries and Fallopian tubes situated on the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text: Who has described the prognostic evaluation for PID?
questions.solution:
Boer-Meisel has described the prognostic evaluation for PID. It depends upon the following:

  1. Extent of adhesions
  2. Nature of adhesions such as flimsy or dense.
  3. Size of hydrosalpinx
  4. Macroscopic condition of hydrosalpinx.
  5. The thickness of the tubal wall.

Boer-Meisel system is specifically used for predicting pregnancy outcomes in patients treated for PID.

Gainesville has described the stages of PID depending upon the severity of tubal damage.

  Stages of PID
Stage I Acute salpingitis without peritonitis - no adhesions
Stage II Acute salpingitis with peritonitis- purulent discharge
Stage III Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex
Stage IV Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess
Stage V Tuberculous salpingitis

Westrom has reported that women with one previous attack of PID have a predisposition to another attack.

questions.text: Most common organ that herniates in Morgagni’s hernia is ______
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the most common herniating structure in a Morgagni hernia.

Morgagni Hernia:

  • A hernia in the anterior part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments
  • The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.

Morgagni hernia:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the therapeutic modality shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows photochemotherapy (PUVA therapy), used for the treatment of vitiligo. It causes suppression of T lymphocyte action.

The UVA spectrum is 320-400 nm. When it is used in combination with an oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer, it is known as PUVA therapy. The most frequently-used oral psoralens are 8‐methoxy psoralen (8‐MOP) and 5‐methoxy psoralen (5‐MOP).

The mechanisms of action of PUVA:

  • Inhibition of DNA replication - DNA cross‐linking by psoralen photoadducts
  • Langerhans cell depletion
  • Immunosuppressive effects on T‐lymphocyte function
  • Stimulation of melanogenesis
  • Migration and the restoration of Th17/regulatory T-cell imbalance in psoriasis

Indications of PUVA therapy:

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption
  • Cutaneous T cell lymphoma

The UVB part of the spectrum is 280-320 nm. Lamps utilizing the 311-313 nm frequencies are called narrow‐band UV (NBUVB). UVB phototherapy has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties. 

Vitiligo may respond both to NB‐UVB and PUVA. NBUVB is more effective than PUVA but the response is variable and treatment usually has to be prolonged, often over many months to a year or more.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Socratic type of communication?
questions.solution:
A panel discussion is an example of Socratic type of communication. 

Didactic communication Socratic communication
One-way communication Two-way communication
Knowledge is imposed and learning is authoritative Learning is active and democratic
No audience participation Audience share opinions, ideas, and questions
Does not influence human behavior Influences human behavior
Feedback absent Feedback present

Examples of Socratic communication include:

  • Symposium
  • Panel discussions
  • Workshops

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent rhinitis, chronic nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage, multiple ethmoidal polyps and the microscopic appearance of conical vesicles with conidia over two-thirds of the vesicle is suggestive of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus spp. can lead to the following types of sinusitis:

  1. Acute invasive sinusitis: It affects immunocompromised patients. They present with fever, nasal or facial discomfort, blocked nose and bloody nasal discharge. Pale, dusky or necrotic tissue will be present within the sinuses.
  2. Chronic aspergillus sinusitis:
    • Fungal ball of sinus: The maxillary sinus, most commonly, is filled with an aspergillus ball. No tissue invasion is present.
    • Chronic invasive sinusitis: There is slow destruction of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with bone destruction and localised spread. Patients present with chronic nasal discharge and blockage, loss of the sense of smell and persistent headache. Involvement of the orbit results in proptosis and blindness.
    • Chronic granulomatous sinusitis: Patients present with facial swelling and unilateral proptosis. Biopsied tissue shows granulomatous (not necrotic) reaction.
  3. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: Patients present with chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On microscopy, eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen.

On microscopic examination of the sinus or polyp tissue, hyaline, septate, acute branching hyphae of Aspergillus spp. can be seen. The various species can be differentiated based on the appearance of the conidiophores. In Aspergillus fumigatus, the vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper two-thirds of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus has a globular vesicle. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger has a globular-shaped vesicle. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broom appearance).

questions.text: Before an elective surgery, the prothrombin time of a patient was measured to be 14 seconds. The function of which of the following factors is not assessed by this test?
questions.solution:
The prothrombin time (PT) assay assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway. As factor XII is only involved in the intrinsic pathway of clotting, it cannot be assessed by this method.

PT assay helps in checking the function of factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen. To perform this test, tissue factor, phospholipids, and calcium are added to plasma and the time required to form a fibrin clot is recorded.

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Prolonged PT 

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

 Factor VII deficiency 

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Warfarin

Prolonged aPTT

Evaluates intrinsic pathway factors

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factors VIII, IX, XI deficiency

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

von Willebrand disease

 Heparin, lupus anticoagulant, acquired von Willebrand disease

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

Evaluates common pathway factors

Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease

Severe vitamin K deficiency

Direct thrombin inhibitor-argatroban, dabigatran

Direct factor Xa inhibitor-rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban

Fondaparinux

questions.text: Which condition is associated with the pancake brain sign on CT?
questions.solution:
The pancake brain sign represents the appearance of the cerebral parenchyma in the case of alobar holoprosencephaly.

Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain caused by the defective formation of the prosencephalon and impaired induction of forebrain structures. It is commonly associated with trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), with alobar holoprosencephaly representing the most severe form. Features of holoprosencephaly include a single ventricular cavity (boomerang-shaped/horseshoe ventricle), fusion of frontal lobes, corpus callosum dysgenesis and other abnormalities.

The following image is a CT brain showing a 'pancake appearance' in alobar holoprosencephaly:

Other options:

Option B: Lissencephaly represents a group of disorders caused by defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th and 14th gestational weeks, resulting in a lack of development of gyri and sulci. The image given below shows lissencephaly:

 

 

Option C: Schizencephaly is the presence of unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres due to an abnormality of morphogenesis. The image given below shows schizencephaly:

 

 

Option D: Porencephaly is an extremely rare cephalic disorder involving encephalomalacia. It is a neurological disorder of the central nervous system characterized by cysts or cavities within the cerebral hemisphere.

questions.text: You are asked to determine the sex of a person from the skeletal remains found on an empty site. Which of the following bones is most accurate for the same?
questions.solution:
The whole pelvis is the most reliable bone for sex determination.

Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones and pelvis >95%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Long bones and skull - 90-95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Long bones alone – 80-90%

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peak expiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes is important for the pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset of severe breathlessness and wheezing with a reduced peak expiratory flow rate is suggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma. 5-lipoxygenase enzyme is important for the pathogenesis of this condition. 

Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediators like leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.). Leukotrienes are produced from the breakdown of arachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway. 

Leukotrienes are eicosanoic acid derivatives formed in leukocytes, mast cells, platelets, and macrophages. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway. Leukotrienes also cause increased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes. Thus, they are involved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

questions.text: A female infant was born in a community hospital by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 34 weeks of gestation. 30 minutes later, the baby’s breathing became excessively laboured. Despite providing non-invasive ventilation, the baby died. Post-mortem histopathological examination of the lung showed thick pink membranes lining the small, collapsed alveolar spaces and necrotic debris, mainly within the respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts, and unopened alveoli. What are these membranes chiefly composed of?
questions.solution:
The history of respiratory distress in a premature baby (34 weeks) and a biopsy showing pink (hyaline) membranes in the alveoli is indicative of hyaline membrane disease (HMD). The hyaline membranes are composed of layers of fibrin-rich edema fluid and necrotic cells of lining alveoli. Diffuse ischemic damage to the alveoli causes the transudation of proteins into the alveoli to form the hyaline membrane.

Hyaline membrane disease (HMD), also known as infantile respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) or respiratory distress syndrome of newborns (RDS) is a syndrome in premature infants caused by developmental insufficiency of pulmonary surfactant production and structural immaturity of the lungs.

questions.text: A couple brought their 11-month-old child for an eye exam when they noticed that his left upper eyelid was in a lower position than his right one. The mother also noticed that his left upper eyelid goes "up and down” when she breastfeeds him. His delivery was unremarkable. When the baby opens his mouth or sucks his thumb, the left eyelid ptosis disappears. What is the pathology behind this condition?

choices.text: Superior division of the third cranial nerve is misdirected
Sympathetic nerves to Muller's muscles are misdirected
Ophthalmic division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected
Mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. In this condition, the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.

Some cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. The vast majority are unilateral. Signs include retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement. Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth. Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

The following image shows a woman with Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon. See how her right eyelid ptosis retracts with the opening of the mouth.

questions.text:
In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease?
  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive 1000 50
Test negative 500 3450
Total 1500 3500
questions.solution:
Prevalence is given by the formula: 

In this scenario, the number of cases: 1000+500 = 1500.

Total population: 5000

Prevalence= 1500/5000 × 100 = 30%.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Which hormone is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH) is the first to fall in Sheehan syndrome. The hormones are affected in the order of GH → Prolactin → LH and FSH → ACTH → TSH

Sheehan syndrome refers to postpartum pituitary necrosis following severe postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland undergoes hypertrophy with increased blood supply. This makes it susceptible to ischemia and infarction when there is severe hypovolemia.

The clinical presentation depends on the amount of damage to the pituitary.

  • Mild - can go unnoticed for many years
  • Moderate - develops over months
    • Lactation failure
    • Failure to resume menses
    • Mild fatigue and anorexia
  • Severe - endocrine emergency that develops within few days
    • Hypotension and shock
    • Severe hypoglycemia
    • Lactation failure

GH deficiency is very common in Sheehan’s syndrome because somatotrophs are located in the lower and lateral regions of the pituitary gland, and are most likely to be damaged by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine receptor?
questions.solution:
The inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine receptor is beta-carboline.  

It impedes the action of GABA and can cause anxiogenic, convulsive, and memory-enhancing effects.

Option A: Barbiturates (phenobarbitone) are agonists at an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor that facilitate the action of GABA.

Option C: Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor.

Option D: Picrotoxin blocks Cl- channel non-competitively.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

Related Pearl: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

Type of anemia

Microcytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Thalassemia trait

Basophilic stippling, target cells 

Iron-deficiency

Elliptocytes, target cells

Sideroblastic anemia

Pappenheimer bodies, RBC dimorphism, ringed sideroblasts (Perl’s stain) 

Macrocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Myelodysplastic syndrome

Hypogranular or hypolobulated neutrophils, blast cells, giant or hypogranular platelets, Pappenheimer bodies

Minor population of hypochromic / microcytic cells (dimorphic), poikilocytosis 

Megaloblastic anemia

Hypersegmented neutrophils (>5 lobes), ovalocytes

Hemolysis

Polychromasia (purple reticulocyte) +/- spherocytes 

Chronic liver disease

Target cells 

Normocytic anemia

Diagnosis

Peripheral blood smear

Haemolytic anemia 

Anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, polychromasia, nucleated red cells 

Hereditary spherocytosis

RBC lack central zone of pallor, reticulocytosis

Glucose-6-Phosphate-Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding solitary rectal ulcers?

choices.text: Commonly seen on the posterior wall
Rectal bleeding Is a common presentation
Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice

questions.solution:
A solitary rectal ulcer is usually located on the anterior rectal wall, 6-8 cm from the anal verge.

It commonly presents with rectal bleeding in the setting of chronic straining or constipation. Histology reveals a thick layer of fibrosis obliterating the lamina propria and a central fibrinous exudate.

Colonoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnostic evaluation, while defecography (proctography) is the radiologic procedure of choice.

Stapled trans-anal rectal resection(STARR procedure) is the management of choice.

questions.text: A microbiologist studying Vibrio cholera added sulphuric acid to a 24-hour peptone culture of the organism and a reddish-pink color developed. Which of the following is true about the test he performed?

choices.text: It is known as methyl red test
A nitrosoindole compound is formed giving it the red colour
The red colour is obtained due to pigment production by the bacteria
The red colour is obtained due to acid & gas production by Vibrio

questions.solution:
The test described here is the 'cholera red reaction' given by Vibrio cholera. When few drops of concentrated sulphuric acid are added to a 24-hour peptone water culture, a reddish-pink colour develops due to the formation of nitrosoindole. Vibrio cholerae reduce nitrates to nitrites and convert tryptophan to indole. These two properties contribute to the cholera red reaction. 

Other options:

Option A: The methyl red (MR) test is used to detect the production of sufficient acid during the fermentation of glucose by bacteria. It is used to classify Enterobacteriacae.

Option C: Vibrio cholera does not produce any colored pigment.

Option D: Vibrio ferments carbohydrates leading to production of acid but no gas.

questions.text: Which of the following formulae is correct?
questions.solution:
True renal plasma flow (RPF) is obtained by dividing effective renal plasma flow (ERPF) by extraction ratio.

When we inject para-aminohippuric acid, 90% of it is filtered through the glomerulus at the rate of 625mL per minute - which is the effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). Using that, to we calculate the true RPF,  we divide it by the extraction ratio to account for the 10% that is not filtered by dividing the ERPF by 0.9, hence getting the final value of ~ 700mL per minute

When peripheral venous plasma concentration of PAH is used for calculation of RPF, RPF obtained is called effective renal plasma flow (ERPF). This is because PAH concentration is essentially identical to that in the arterial plasma reaching the kidney.

questions.text: Richest source of vitamin D is:
questions.solution:
• Halibut liver oil is the richest source of vitamin D. 
  • Other rich sources of vitamin D are cod liver oil and shark liver oil.

Note: Halibut liver oil is also a rich source of vitamin A

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes do not contain selenocysteine at its active sites?
questions.solution:
Methyltransferase does not contain selenocysteine at its active sites.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions.

Examples include:

  • Thioredoxin reductase
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Deiodinase
  • Selenoprotein P
  • Glycine reductase

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with a thyroid swelling underwent thyroidectomy and the histopathological examination of the specimen shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Orphan Annie eye nuclei seen on histopathological examination of a neck swelling in a middle-aged female suggests a diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy with a female preponderance and peaking in the 3rd-5th decade.

Risk factors include radiation exposure and a family history of thyroid carcinoma. Mostly, patients are asymptomatic or they might present with a palpable thyroid nodule. It mainly metastasizes through the lymphatic route.

Comprehensive thyroid ultrasound with bilateral central and lateral neck lymph nodes mapping should be done as part of the imaging workup. Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI of the neck and chest and intraluminal imaging (laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, or esophagoscopy) may be required in patients with potentially more advanced local and regional disease.

Management includes

  • ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy for a low-risk, unilateral, 1-4 cm tumor without extrathyroidal extension/ evidence of metastatic disease as well as for a tumor that is < 1 cm in size. 
  • total thyroidectomy if high risk of recurrence.

The below image shows orphan Annie eye nuclei-

Histopathological features:

  • Branching papillae
  • Orphan Annie eye nuclei are nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin  
  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcified structures within the papillae

 

Other options-

Option B: Follicular carcinoma shows uniform cells forming small follicles and they are filled with colloid and normal thyroid tissue. The below image shows follicular thyroid carcinoma.

 

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma has polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests or trabeculae and contains amyloid deposits in the stroma. The below image shows medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma shows large pleomorphic giant cells, spindle cells, and, mixed cells. The below image shows anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for fixed drug eruption?
questions.solution:
Glans penis is the best answer among the given options. Fixed drug eruptions(FDE) can occur anywhere in the body. However, 50% of FDE occurs in the genital and oral mucosa. The other common sites are palms and soles.

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

  • NSAID‐induced FDE - genitals and lips
  • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE - genitals
  • Metamizole‐induced FDE - trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine‐induced FDE - face

The image below shows hyperpigmentation on the glans penis- healed fixed drug eruption.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presented with increasing abdominal girth and malaise. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was 6 cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies. They are composed of intermediate keratin filaments.

Mallory bodies are also seen in the following conditions:

  • Morbid obesity
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Wilson’s disease
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis

There are several types of cytoskeletal proteins such as microtubules, thin actin filaments, thick myosin filaments, and intermediate filaments (10 nm).

The intermediate filaments provide a flexible intracellular scaffold that organizes the cytoplasm and resists the forces applied to the cell.

They are divided into five classes: 

  • Keratin filaments - characteristic of epithelial cells (forms Mallory Denk bodies)
  • Neurofilaments - neurons (forms neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease)
  • Desmin filaments - muscle cells
  • Vimentin filaments - connective tissue cells
  • Glial filaments - astrocytes

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy on examination is found to have genital development corresponding to Tanner stage 1 and his height is below the 3rd Percentile on growth charting. What is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Failure of development of pubertal features by the age of 14 years in male is suggestive of Delayed Puberty.

The most common cause of delayed puberty in males and females is a constitutional delay in growth and puberty. Lack of pubertal changes in boys by the age of 14 years is suggestive of delayed puberty. Delayed puberty is more common in boys than in girls.

questions.text: Which of the following is a subepidermal disease?
questions.solution:
Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal vesiculobullous disorder.

In bullous pemphigoid, there is subepidermal separation at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ). Eosinophilic and neutrophilic infiltration are noted. It is not associated with acantholysis.

Related Pearl: Classification of Vesiculobullous Disorders

According to Pathology

  • Immunobullous disorders/ Primary blistering disease: occur due to autoimmunity

Intraepidermal

Subepidermal

Pemphigus vulgaris

Bullous pemphigoid

Pemphigus foliaceous

Pemphigus vegetans
