 Pemphigus erythematosus  
  • Mechanobullous disorders: Due to defect in the structure of epidermis
    • Epidermolysis bullosa
    • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Other disorders
    • Infections - VZV, HSV, Bullous impetigo, SSSS
    • Metabolic - Porphyria, Diabetes, Hemodialysis
    • Drug eruptions - Fixed drug eruption, Steven Johnson Syndrome, Erythema Multiforme

According to Site

Intraepidermal

Sub-epidermal (Dermo-epidermal)

1. Subcorneal (granular layer)

  • Pemphigus foliaceous & erythematosus
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  • Miliaria crystalina
  • Bullous impetigo
  • Friction blister
  • Subcorneal pustular dermatosis

2. Spinous layer

  • Eczematous (atopic) dermatitis
  • HSV/VZV infection
  • Molluscum contagiosum
  • Familial benign pemphigus (Hailey-hailey disease)

3. Suprabasal

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Darrier’s disease

4. Basal layer

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

1. Junctional (at basal lamina)

  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis

2. Dermolytic (below basal lamina)

  • Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita
  • Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophicans
  • Deep burns
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

questions.text: All are true about Streptococcus pyogenes except

choices.text: Streptolysin O is active in reduced state
Streptokinase is produced from Group  A β-hemolytic streptococci
Pyrogenic toxin A is plasmid mediated

questions.solution:
Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin A is not plasmid mediated, it is phage mediated.

Other options:

Streptodornase also called as deoxyribonuclease( DNAse ) is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes. It causes depolymerization of DNA, which helps to liquefy the thick pus and is responsible for the thin serous character of streptococcal exudate. Four antigenically distinct DNAases a, b, c, and d have been recognized, of which type b is the most antigenic in human beings.

Streptolysin O is so called because it is oxygen labile. It is inactive in the oxidized form and active in the reduced state.

Streptokinase (SK) is a plasminogen activator produced by many strains of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in:
questions.solution:
The pressure-volume curve is shifted to the left in Mitral stenosis.

The PV loop is shifted to the right when there is volume overload (increased EDV).
The PV loop is shifted to the left in case of increased contractility or decreased compliance (decreased EDV).

Effect of Valvular Diseases on PV loop:

  • Mitral stenosis: Left and down.
  • Mitral regurgitation: Width increased and height decreased.
  • Aortic stenosis: Tall with steep slope.
  • Aortic regurgitation: Right and tall.

questions.text: A 50-year-old housewife with diabetic nephropathy and receiving dialysis weekly comes to your clinic with an accidental burn on her left hand. On examination, 2nd-degree burns are seen. Which of the following opioids should not be prescribed to her for analgesia?
questions.solution:
Pethidine (meperidine) should not be prescribed to her as it is contraindicated in patients with renal failure.

In renal failure, there is an accumulation of its metabolite norpethidine which causes excitatory syndrome consisting of hallucinations, tremors, muscle twitches, and convulsions. Therefore, pethidine is avoided in renal failure patients.

Methadone, alfentanil, and fentanyl primarily undergo hepatic metabolism.

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: The term "balanced anaesthesia" was coined by the same person who lobbied in 1939 to get anaesthesia recognized as a speciality by the American Medical Association. Who is this individual?
questions.solution:
John Lundy coined the term balanced anaesthesia in 1926.

He was instrumental in the formation of the American Board of Anesthesiology and chaired the American Medical Association’s Section on Anesthesiology for 17 years.

Balanced anaesthesia involves the use of multiple anaesthetic agents and techniques to produce the different components of anaesthesia, i.e.:

  • Analgesia
  • Amnesia
  • Muscle relaxation
  • Abolition of autonomic reflexes

Option B: James Young Simpson introduced chloroform

Option C: Edmund Boyle invented the anaesthetic machine 

Option D: Oliver Wendell coined the term anaesthesia

questions.text: What is the preferred management in an adult with a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?

choices.text: Closed reduction with above elbow cast
Closed reduction with below elbow cast

questions.solution:
Galeazzi fracture-dislocation in an adult is managed by internal fixation with compression plating of the radius. In children, closed reduction is usually successful.

Note: Galeazzi's sign is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip where the infant's knees are flexed and approximated when lying down. One knee is higher than the other in developmental dysplasia.

The below image shows Galeazzi's sign. 

Related Pearl: Fractures of necessity

Fractures of necessity are those that require surgery for management. These include:

  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus 
  • Displaced fractured of olecranon and patella
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation 
  • Monteggia fracture in adults
  • Intra-articular fractures

questions.text: Which is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
G6PD Mediterranean is the most severe variant of G6PD deficiency.

Two variants, designated as G6PD– and G6PD Mediterranean, cause most of the clinically significant hemolytic anaemias. The half-life of G6PD- is moderately reduced, whereas that of G6PD Mediterranean is markedly reduced. Hence, the severity of the Mediterranean variant is more.

The most common normal variant is G6PD B.

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her parents with a 1-month history of the following skin lesions, which are present all over her body. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: Due to gain of function mutation in KIT gene
Age of onset in adults is between 20-40 years
It is a type of systemic mastocytosis
It can present with bullous lesions

questions.solution:
The given image shows urticaria pigmentosa lesions on the trunk of a child. It is the commonest type of cutaneous mastocytosis. It occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. 

The mast cells accumulate in tissues due to a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT. The symptoms occur due to the release of mast cell-derived mediators. The age of onset is in the first year in the childhood type and 20–40 years in the adult type.

It presents with numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques, or nodules in a symmetrical distribution. Lesions can occur anywhere but are common over trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared. It can also present with bullous lesions that heal without scarring.

Treatment includes: 

  • Avoiding physical stimuli that trigger mast cell degranulation- temperature extremes, pressure, alcohol
  • Antihistamines
  • Mast cell stabilizers
  • Topical and oral corticosteroids
  • PUVA therapy
  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with academic and behavioral problems at school over the past year was diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. On neuroimaging, which of the following is most likely to be seen?

choices.text: Pathologic alterations in the frontal lobe
Structural anomalies in the frontal lobe
Lesion in the Ascending Reticular Activating System

questions.solution:
Functional neuroimaging studies show frontal lobe hypometabolism in patients with ADHD.

The frontal lobe maintains attention, arousal, or the establishment and maintenance of an awake state. This appears to require at least three brain regions:

  • Ascending reticular activating system (ARAS)
  • Intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus
  • Frontal lobes

In ADHD, although no specific pathological lesions are found in the ARAS, thalamic or cortical level, functional neuroimaging indicates frontal lobe hypometabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
questions.solution:
Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. 

The development of the middle ear:

  • The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation.
  • Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks.
  • The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck’s triad?
questions.solution:
Pulsus paradoxus is not part of Beck’s triad. Pulsus paradoxus is seen in cardiac tamponade. However, it is not a part of Beck's triad.

Beck’s triad is seen in cardiac tamponade and it includes: 

  • Hypotension
  • Soft or absent heart sounds
  • Jugular venous distension

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space significant enough to cause an obstruction to the inflow of blood to the ventricles. This reduces cardiac output and arterial pressure causing hypotension. 

This also causes a greater than the normal reduction in the systolic arterial blood pressure producing pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration.

Other causes of pulsus paradoxus include:

  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Severe obstructive lung disease
  • Hemorrhagic shock

The echocardiography clip below shows the swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: What is found more in human milk as compared to cow’s milk?
questions.solution:
The percentage of lactose in human milk is greater than that in cow’s milk.

Differences between human milk and cow's milk are shown below:

Nutrient Human milk (per 100 mL) Cow's milk (per 100 mL)
Protein 1.1 g 3.5 g
Calories 67 kcal 62 kcal
Casein 30–40% (rich in whey protein) 80%
Lactose 7.4 g 4.5 g
Fat  3.5 g 4g
Na+ (mEq/L) 6.5 25
K+ (mEq/L) 14 35
Osmolality (mOsm/L) 290 350
calcium/phosphate >2 <2
Vitamin K 1.5 µg 6 µg
Iron 0.29–0.45 mg 0.01-0.38 mg
Vitamin D 0.5-10 IU 0.5-4.5 IU

Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid.

questions.text: Which layer of the epidermis is underdeveloped in the very low birth weight infants in the initial 7 days?
questions.solution:
Stratum corneum is underdeveloped in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants in the initial 7 days. In preterm infants, the stratum corneum is permeable and becomes similar to the adult and full-term infant after 2-3 weeks of postnatal maturation.

The development of the layers of the epidermis starts from below upwards. Therefore, the stratum basale is the first to form and the stratum corneum is the last layer to form.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease has been undergoing hemodialysis for the past 4 years. Deposition of which of the following is likely in this condition?
questions.solution:
Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis as a result of the deposition of β2-microglobulin.

This protein is present in high concentrations in the serum of persons with renal disease. The protein is retained in the circulation because it cannot be filtered through the dialysis membranes.

It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in the carpal ligament of the wrist, it leads to the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.

With new dialysis filters, the incidence of this complication has decreased substantially.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male, who works in a factory that manufactures explosives, came to the OPD with a peculiar complaint. He says that he gets headaches and feels transient dizziness every Monday after his weekend off. Exposure to which compound is likely to produce his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient is most likely suffering from Monday disease which is associated with exposure to nitroglycerin.

Continuous exposure to high levels of nitrates can occur in the chemical industry, especially where explosives are manufactured.

When contamination of the workplace with nitrate compounds is severe, workers find that upon starting their week, they suffer headaches and transient dizziness. After a day or so back at work, tolerance develops. Over the weekend, when exposure to the chemicals is reduced, tolerance disappears, so symptoms recur each Monday.

questions.text: Sexual asphyxia is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Sexual asphyxia (autoerotic asphyxia/asphyxiophilia) is seen in masochism and transvestism. 

Pressure on carotid vessels/partial airway obstruction leads to cerebral hypoxia and impaired consciousness. This causes erotic hallucinations and sexual pleasure. A controlled degree of mechanical asphyxia is produced, but accidental deaths can happen.

Option A: Lust murder is an extreme case of sadism where murder serves as a stimulus for a sexual act. Death is not accidental, as is in the case of sexual asphyxia. 

Option C: Sexual oralism is obtaining sexual pleasure from the application of the mouth to the sexual organs. 

Option D: Frotteurism is a perversion mostly seen in males, where they obtain sexual gratification from rubbing their genitalia on unsuspecting females.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: Fine reticular hyperpigmentation with pits near the angle of mouth is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Dowling-Degos disease is a skin condition characterized by a lacy or net-like (reticulate) pattern of hyperpigmentation, particularly in the flexural areas.

It is associated with scattered comedo-like lesions (dark dot follicles) and pitted acneiform scars near the angle of the mouth.

Option D: Reticulate acropigmentation of Kitamura presents with hyperpigmented atrophic macules on the hand dorsa and “pits” on the palms and soles with abnormal dermatoglyphics.

Option A and B: Rothmund Thomson syndrome and Cockayne syndrome are genodermatoses associated with defective DNA repair and photosensitivity.

questions.text: Renal arterial hypertension leads to _______
questions.solution:
Renal arterial hypertension leads to high renin hypertension.

Critical levels of stenosis lead to a reduction in perfusion pressure that :

  • Activates the renin-angiotensin system(a key step in the development of renovascular hypertension)
  • Reduces sodium excretion
  • Activates sympathetic adrenergic pathways

Renovascular hypertension can be treated with agents that block the renin-angiotensin system and other drugs that modify these pressor pathways.

The causes of low renin hypertension are as follows:

  • Low renin essential hypertension (LREH)
  • Primary aldosteronism (eg: Conn syndrome)
  • Liddle syndrome
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor mutation
  • Glucocorticoid resistance
  • Gordon syndrome
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)

questions.text: In the clinical assessment of patients with alcohol use disorder, which of the following is not used?
questions.solution:
Fagerström tolerance questionnaire and its revision, Fagerström Test for Nicotine Dependence (FTND) are used in the assessment of nicotine addiction related to cigarette smoking. It contains six items that evaluate the quantity of cigarette consumption, the compulsion to use, and dependence.

Option B: Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ-Q) was developed to assess the severity of alcohol dependence. 

Option C: The CAGE questionnaire is used to assess whether or not there is a problem with dependence. 

  • C - Have you ever felt you ought to cut down on your drinking?
  • A - Have people annoyed you by criticizing your drinking?
  • G - Have you ever felt guilty or bad about your drinking?
  • E - Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover (eye-opener)?

One 'yes' response raises a suspicion of an alcohol use problem and more than one is a strong indication of abuse or dependence. 

Option D: The Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT) is a 10-item screening tool developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) to assess alcohol consumption, drinking behaviors, and alcohol-related problems. The AUDIT also helps to identify alcohol dependence and some specific consequences of harmful drinking.

questions.text: Which of the following has been most commonly implicated as a cause of dialysis-induced hypotension in patients?
questions.solution:
Acetate is used as a buffer in the dialysate solution. It is the most common cause of dialysis-induced hypotension because of its vasodilatory and cardio-depressive effects.

For this reason, acetate is less commonly used these days and has been largely replaced by bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 51-year-old, diabetic patient presents with the following features during a village health camp. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Due to immunosuppression caused by elevated glucose levels
Repeated injury leads to Charcot's foot
Glycemic control and antibiotic therapy is first line managment
Sensory nerves are affected in the late stage of disease

questions.solution:
The image and clinical scenario are suggestive of diabetic gangrene of the foot. It is accompanied by sensory loss in the early stage of the disease and motor involvement in the late stage. 

Diabetic gangrene is caused by a combination of three factors:

  • Ischemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction,
  • Peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, which leads to trophic skin changes
  • Immunosuppression is caused by excess sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infection

Diabetic gangrene is accompanied by loss of sensation and reflexes which lead to repeated injury. There occurs an imbalance between the flexors and extensors of the foot which causes deformities known as Charcot's foot (neuropathic joints).

Initial treatment comprises strict glycemic control and antibiotic therapy. The gangrene is treated by drainage of pus, debridement of dead tissue with local amputation of necrotic digits.

questions.text: What is the total number of double bonds present in arachidonic acid?
questions.solution:
Arachidonic acid contains 4 double bonds in its structure. 

Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated omega-6 fatty acid (PUFA). It has 4 double bonds present in a cis configuration. It is present in the phospholipids of cell membranes and is the precursor of prostanoids such as prostaglandins, thromboxanes, and leukotrienes.

Number of Double Bonds in Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids

Polyunsaturated fatty acids

No. of double bonds

Linoleic Acid

Linolenic Acid

Arachidonic Acid

Timnodonic Acid

Given below is an image of the structure of arachidonic acid.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are unlikely to develop iron overload?
questions.solution:
Thalassemia minor does not result in iron overload. Secondary hemochromatosis or iron overload is characterized by the deposition of iron in parenchymal cells.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text: Pseudo-inclusions are seen in ______.
questions.solution:
Invaginations of the cytoplasm may give the appearance of intranuclear inclusions (“pseudo-inclusions”) or intranuclear grooves in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Nuclear features of papillary carcinoma of thyroid

  • Nuclear overlapping
  • Ground-glass appearance(Orphan Annie nuclei)
  • Nuclear grooving
  • Nuclear crowding
  • Dusty chromatin
  • Pale chromatin
  • Intranuclear inclusion bodies,

 The diagnosis of papillary carcinoma can be made on the basis of these nuclear features, even in the absence of papillary architecture.

Image: Pseudoinclusions in papillary carcinoma

questions.text: A patient needs to undergo a packed red blood cell (PRBC) transfusion due to severe anemia. Before administration, you must make sure the unit of PRBC is at a temperature of_______.
questions.solution:
PRBC transfusion is to be done after warming it to a temperature of 37°C.

Packed RBCs are stored at 1-6°C. Transfusion at this temperature will lead to profound hypothermia. If the body temperature decreases to less than 30°C, ventricular irritability and cardiac arrest may occur. Shivering from even mild hypothermia increases metabolic demands and is counterproductive to tissue perfusion, especially in settings where anemia or hypoperfusion is contributing to tissue ischemia.

Hypothermia together with low levels of 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) in stored blood can cause a marked leftward shift of the hemoglobin–oxygen dissociation curve which can lead to tissue hypoxia.

The ideal method of warming blood is to pass it through plastic coils or cassettes in a warm water bath(37°C to 38°C) or warming plates.

 

Red cells are normally stored at 1–6°C, but may be frozen in a hypertonic glycerol solution for up to 10 years. This technique is usually reserved for the storage of blood with rare phenotypes.

questions.text: Multiple inmates at a prison are suspected to have epidemic typhus following an arthropod infestation. Which of the following vectors is implicated in the spread of this disease?
questions.solution:
Louse (image B), Pediculus humanus corporis, transmits epidemic typhus. 

Gaol fever/ Jail fever/ epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

Related Pearl: Human diseases caused by the Rickettsia and Orientia species

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: A prison inmate who was in long-term solitary confinement is being subjected to a neuropsychiatric evaluation. He is asked what the colour of the sky is, and he answers that it is green. What is this symptom called?
questions.solution:
When the person gives a wrong answer to a question, but it is very similar to the actual answer, it is called vorbeireden, which means to give 'approximate answers'. 

Here, the person answered 'green' for the colour of the sky. The content of the reply shows that they have understood the nature of the question, but responded wrongly or approximately by talking about an associated topic.

Vorbeireden is a feature of Ganser syndrome (hysterical pseudodementia), commonly found in prison inmates.

Option A: Neologism refers to making new words that do not exist and using them meaninglessly, as seen in schizophrenia. e.g., "The world is not 'gooder' for people like me". 

Option B: Verbigeration is the meaningless and stereotyped repetition of words or phrases, seen in schizophrenia. e.g., "I want to go home go home go home".

Option D: Circumstantiality is the inclusion of irrelevant details and talking in a roundabout manner, but the patient's thought ultimately reaches the answer.

Controversial : The classification of OCD as a certain form of thought is debatable based on the resource. Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry (11th Edition) lists it under disorders of content of thought, whilst Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (4th Edition) mentions it under disorders of possession of thought. Hence, the answer depends on the book referred by the examiner while framing the question.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

questions.text: A primigravida on screening was found to have a fasting blood glucose of more than 100 mg/dl. Which of the following medications will you not prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Tolbutamide is not used for the treatment of gestational diabetes. 

First-generation sulfonylureas such as tolbutamide and chlorpropamide can cause teratogenicity, neonatal hypoglycemia, and fetal hyperinsulinemia.

First-line glycemic control agents in pregnancy:

  • Insulin
  • Glyburide 
  • Metformin

questions.text: A patient with trastuzumab-refractory breast cancer is started on lapatinib. Which of the following statements is true regarding this drug?

choices.text: Dual inhibitor of VEGFR and HER 2 tyrosine kinase
Dual inhibitor of MET and HER 2 tyrosine kinase
Dual inhibitor of VEGFR and MET tyrosine kinase
Dual inhibitor of EGFR and HER 2 tyrosine kinase

questions.solution:
Lapatinib is a dual inhibitor of epidermal growth factor (EGFR) and human epidermal growth factor 2 (HER2) tyrosine kinase.

Lapatinib in combination with capecitabine is approved for the treatment of patients with metastatic HER2-positive and trastuzumab-refractory breast cancer.

Trastuzumab deruxtecan is a newer drug recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of adults with unresectable or metastatic, HER2 positive breast cancer. It is a human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2)-directed antibody and topoisomerase inhibitor(toxic to cancer cells).

questions.text: An elderly man was diagnosed with hypertension 2 years ago and has been on losartan. During a routine health checkup, his HbA1c was found to be 7.3%. Which of the following is a better alternative to losartan for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has hypertension and diabetes mellitus (HbA1c >6.5% is diagnostic for diabetes). Telmisartan would be a better alternative to losartan in patients with both hypertension and diabetes, due to its additional PPAR gamma agonist action.

PPAR gamma agonists act by inducing several insulins sensitizing genes and thereby reducing the overall insulin resistance. 

While other angiotensin receptor blockers have been found to have PPAR gamma action, telmisartan has the highest and has been extensively studied in diabetes.

questions.text: Which of the following anticancer drug is excreted by lungs?
questions.solution: 5-Fluorouracil is rapidly metabolized in the liver to produce inactive metabolites that are either converted into carbon dioxide and eliminated via lungs or into fluoro-beta-alanine that is excreted via urine.

questions.text: Given below is the CT abdomen of a patient who presented with diarrhea. He is most likely to be suffering from _____.
questions.solution:
The CT image depicts the accordion sign seen in pseudomembranous colitis.

Clostridium difficle infection (CDI) commonly caused by the disruption of the commensal colonic microflora, due to prolonged antimicrobial use, especially antibiotics like cephalosporins, ampicillin, clindamycin, and fluoroquinolones. The more severe form of CDI is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC).

Toxigenic Clostridium difficile produces toxin A (an enterotoxin) and toxin B (a cytotoxin), damaging the epithelial-cell barrier function and causing diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation, which initially appear as small whitish-yellow plaques and later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. The patient also presents with fever, abdominal pain, and leukocytosis.

On CT imaging, accordion sign, also referred to as concertina sign, may be seen.  The terms accordion or concertina refer to a harmonica like a musical instrument. The thickened edematous bowel resembles the folds of an accordion. The hyperemic-enhancing mucosa stretched over the thickened submucosal folds produces this appearance. This is also seen when the contrast gets trapped between edematous haustral folds and pseudomembranes of the colon. 

Accordion sign is typical for pseudomembranous colitis but can be also seen in ischemic colitis, AIDS-related colitis, and severe edema from cirrhosis.

The CT image below depicts accordion sign:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A woman gave birth to a stillborn baby. She concealed the birth by secret disposal of the dead body. Which of the following statement is false regarding this situation?

choices.text: She can be imprisoned for a maximum of 2 years
She can be charged under Sec 94 of BNS (IPC 318)
She cannot be charged under Sec 80 of BNS (IPC 304B)
The act is defined under Sec 93 of BNS (IPC 317)

questions.solution:
The given scenario is defined under Section 94 of the BNS (IPC 318), not Sec 93 BNS.

 Section

Deals with

Punishment

BNS 93 (IPC 317)

Exposure and abandonment of child under 12 years by parents

Up to 7 years of imprisonment or fine or both

BNS 94 (IPC 318)

Concealment of birth by secret disposal of the dead body

Up to 2 years of imprisonment or fine or both


Section 80 of BNS (IPC 304B) deals with dowry death.

questions.text: In a patient with hemophilia A, how much can infusion of one unit of factor VIII/kg increase the plasma levels of factor VIII?
questions.solution:
One unit of factor VIII/kg body weight increases the plasma levels of factor VIII levels by 2%. Therefore, for a rise in 1 % in the plasma, half unit/ kg will be required, that is 0.5 units/kg.

It is used in the treatment of hemophilia. One unit of FVIII is the amount of FVIII in 1 mL of plasma.

The dose required for replacement is calculated as :

  • Factor VIII dose = (Target factor VIII levels - baseline factor VIII levels) x bodyweight x 0.5 units/ kg
  • Factor IX (IU) = (Target FIX levels – FIX baseline levels) x bodyweight (kg) x 1 unit/kg

Cryoprecipitate is used when factor concentrates are not available. Each bag of cryoprecipitate contains 80 IU of Factor VIII.

Blood components Composition Indications
Factor VIII concentrates Factor VIII Hemophilia A
Factor IX concentrates Factor IX Hemophilia B
Cryoprecipitate

Fibrinogen

Factor XIII

Factor VIII

VWF

Fibrinogen deficiency, Factor XIII deficiency, von Willebrand disease
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

questions.text: All of the following statements about glucokinase are true in comparison to other hexokinases, except:
questions.solution:
Glucose is the only cellular substrate that can be phosphorylated by glucokinase. 

Glucokinase has a higher Vmax and a higher Km value than hexokinase. This means it requires a higher concentration of glucose for half saturation. Hence, glucokinase functions only when the intracellular concentration of glucose is elevated, as seen immediately after a carbohydrate-rich meal. 

Characteristics Hexokinase Glucokinase
Tissue distribution Most tissues Liver and beta cells of the pancreas
Km Low High

Vmax

 Low High
Inhibition by G6P Yes No
Inducible No Inducible
Clinical significance Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia Less activity in diabetes mellitus
Biological significance Involved in maintaining intracellular glucose concentration  Involved in maintaining blood glucose concentration

Note: Glucokinase acts on other hexoses such as fructose, mannose too. However, in vivo, the Km for this reaction is so high that at the intracellular concentrations available, the activity is not significant. Hence, the best option has been chosen as the answer in this MCQ.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions is associated with ADAMTS13 deficiency?
questions.solution:
ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation.

TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels.

Features of TTP include:

  • Fever
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
  • Transient neurologic deficits
  • Renal failure

Related Pearl: Differences between TTP and HUS

questions.text: Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of chronic pyelonephritis.

Histopathological features of chronic pyelonephritis are:

  • Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization)
  • Chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla
  • Periglomerular fibrosis
  • Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), usually several years after the scarring has occurred and often in the absence of continued infection or persistent vesicoureteral reflux

questions.text: In a patient with a coracoid fracture, the action of which of the following muscle is not hindered?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a coracoid fracture, the action of the long head of triceps muscle is not hindered. It attaches to the infraglenoid tubercle on the lateral border of the scapula and not the coracoid process.

Coracoid process attachements:

  • Origin: 2 muscles - Coracobrachialis (medially) and short head of biceps (laterally)
  • Insertion: 1 muscle - Pectoralis minor
  • 3 ligaments: 
    • Coracoacromial
    • Coracoclavicular
    • Coracohumeral

questions.text: An unbooked primigravida, with no antenatal records, delivers a 2.5kg male baby by normal delivery. While ascertaining the maturity of the child, which of the following would be against a diagnosis of prematurity?
questions.solution:
Thick cartilage with a stiff ear in a newborn is a sign of maturity (not prematurity).

Score Ear
0 Pinna flat and stays folded; no recoil
1 Slightly curved pinna; soft; slow recoil
2 Well-curved pinna; soft but ready recoil
3 Formed & firm, instant recoil
4 Thick cartilage, ear stiff

No creases on the sole, insignificant breast nodule, and empty scrotum are all physical signs of prematurity in a newborn.

Note:

Abundant lanugo hair is not discriminatory evidence of prematurity. This is because neonates of diabetic mothers born as a term or even post-term have abundant lanugo hair, especially over the pinna and upper back.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient complains of double vision that gets worse after he watches television. He also has drooping of the eyelids that gets better after a nap. Serology is positive for anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. A CT scan of his chest is given below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is the most common tumor of the anterior mediastinum.
Masoaka classification system is used for staging.
Tumor size is a reliable indicator of malignancy.
Surgery can be performed through a median sternotomy approach.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of myasthenia gravis along with the CT scan image showing an anterior mediastinal mass are suggestive of thymoma. The only reliable indicator of malignancy in thymoma is the capsular invasion, not tumor size.

Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor and is derived from the thymus gland. Thymomas vary in behavior from benign to aggressively invasive. Masoaka classification system is used to stage thymomas.

Myasthenia gravis is often related to thymomas. Symptoms of myasthenia gravis improve after excision of the thymus gland even in the absence of a thymoma. 

Complete thymectomy is the treatment for thymoma. It can be performed by two approaches:

  • A median sternotomy approach
  • A transcervical approach with or without an additional VATS procedure (Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery) for smaller thymomas

Related Pearl: Locations of the Common Mediastinal Masses

questions.text: Which of the following options is correctly matched?

choices.text: Social institution- the pattern of inter-relations between persons in a society
Socialism- organised complex patterns of behaviour in people with a common interest
Social structure- system of governance based on social ownership
Socialization- the process by which a person imbibes the social beliefs and customes

questions.solution:
Socialization is the process by which a person in a society imbibes its beliefs, customs, etc. through daily interaction with its members.

Social institutions are organized complex patterns of behaviour in which a number of people engage to further a common interest. Examples are families, schools, hospitals, etc.

Socialism is a system of governance in which production and distribution is based on social ownership (and not private ownership). It is aimed at improving the living standard.

Social structure is the pattern of inter-relations between persons in a society.

questions.text: After medical management in ectopic, serum beta hCG level to be monitored weekly till the level is ______
questions.solution: Serum beta hCG level is to be monitored weekly till the level is <5 mIU/L.

questions.text: A 15-year-old child has been recurrently hospitalized for infections, since 2 years of age. After a detailed evaluation, a diagnosis of Kartagener's syndrome was suspected. All of the following are components of the Kartagener triad except _____.
questions.solution:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.

Kartagener’s syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesiacharacterized by the classical triad of:

  • Situs inversus
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis

Primary ciliary dyskinesia (also called immotile cilia syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting ciliary motility. It occurs due to ultrastructural defects in the dynein arm of cilia. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

As ciliary function is necessary to ensure proper rotation of the developing organs in the chest and abdomen. Its absence, will lead to situs inversus or a partial lateralizing abnormality.

Male patients with this condition tend to be infertile, due to asthenospermia (immotile spermatozoa due to impaired sperm flagella function).

questions.text: A researcher is studying mutations in the rhodopsin gene which are responsible for some forms of autosomal dominant retinitis pigmentosa. On which chromosome is this gene located?
questions.solution:
The gene for rhodopsin is located at 3q22.1

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a dystrophy of rods and cones, with rods being primarily affected. It is a genetic disease. The non-hereditary/sporadic type is most common. Among the hereditary types, it can occur in an autosomal dominant (AD), autosomal recessive (AR), or X-linked recessive (XLR) pattern. AD disease generally has the best prognosis.

The presenting feature is night blindness.

Investigations:

  • Perimetry - the initial stage will have ring scotoma, which further develops into tunnel vision.
  • Electroretinography - reveals a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.

Retinitis pigmentosa is a condition with no cure. There are drugs used to slow down the progression such as acetazolamide for concomitant cystoid macular edema. Recently, vitamin A has been recommended, although the efficacy has not been established.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal discomfort. CECT of the abdomen and pelvis shows a heterogeneously enhancing renal mass with a central stellate scar. On resection, the tumor appears mahogany brown. What is the site of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of renal oncocytoma. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. 

It is a benign epithelial neoplasm. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany brown and relatively homogeneous. They are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in one-third of cases.

Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria.

The gross and histological appearances of renal oncocytoma are shown in the images given below:

Oncocytes refer to epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the accumulation of mitochondria). They can arise in various tissues and are referred to as: 

  • Hurthle cells/Ashkenazy cells in the thyroid gland
  • Oxyphilic cells in the parotid gland
  • Apocrine metaplasia in the breast

questions.text: An ultrasound was done on a pregnant Rh-negative patient  to screen for hydrops fetalis. What is the earliest sign that may be seen on USG?
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of hydrops fetalis on a USG is scalp edema. Subcutaneous scalp edema is also known as the Halo sign. 

Other USG signs include:

  • Ascites
  • Pleural effusion 
  • Pericardial effusion 
  • Typical position termed as Buddha's position   

The image below shows skin thickening at the level of the fetal skull, on ultrasonography:

questions.text: A patient with a history of uncomplicated cataract surgery 1 year back, presents with pain, redness, and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer was noted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon and a moderate flare reaction. A smear from the ulcerated area is likely to demonstrate which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens) is typically caused by Pneumococcus. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. 

Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the centre of the cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion.

Risk factors include both surgical and non-surgical ocular trauma, dry eye, chronic corneal disease, immune alterations and contact lenses.

An examination may reveal the following signs:

  • Swelling of lids and blepharospasm
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Ciliary congestion, hypopyon and anterior chamber flare reaction
  • Iridocyclitis 

Image given below shows ulcus serpens.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with pain in the right hip during ambulation for the past few months. There is no history of trauma. An X-ray done is shown below. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation to confirm the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows flattening of the femoral head and degenerative changes associated with avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis of the femoral head. The most sensitive investigation to diagnose avascular necrosis is MRI.

MRI allows identification of avascular necrosis of the femoral head in earlier stages and also determines the exact stage and extent of the pathologic process.

The radiograph below shows the flattening of the femoral head in a patient with avascular necrosis.

The radiographic appearance of avascular necrosis of the femoral head may show the following changes:

  • Sclerosis of the femoral head
  • Flattening or loss of sphericity of femoral head
  • Crescent sign
  • In severe stages, it may show femoral head collapse and arthritic changes in the joint

The image given below shows osteonecrosis of the femoral head seen on an MRI.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as an ideal homicidal poison?
questions.solution:
Thallium is considered an ideal homicidal poison because poisoning with thallium resembles natural death. 

When considering suicide with poison, the suicide victim prefers to terminate life as quickly as possible with the least agony. Whereas for an act of homicide with poison, the criminal would like to kill his victim without creating any suspicion in the mind of the victim or people around.

Following are the characteristics of ideal suicidal and homicidal poisons:

Characteristics Suicidal  Homicidal

Accessibility to the poison

Easy and free

Not particular

Antidotes availability

 Nil Nil

Clinical diagnosis

 Difficult Difficult

Cost of the poison

Cheap 

 Not particular

Metabolism and excretion

 Not particular   Rapid

Onset of signs and symptoms

 Quick and fatal Slow and fatal

Postmortem detection

Difficult

Difficult

Signs and symptoms

Nil/ few

Resemble diseases

Solubility in food/drinks

 Positive  Positive

Examples

Opium, cyanide, barbiturates, organophosphorus compounds

 Arsenic, aconite, thallium, etc

Thallium and organic compounds of fluorine satisfy some of the criteria for an ideal homicidal poison.

Arsenic and aconite are commonly used as homicidal poisons but are not considered ideal homicidal poisons. 

Note: Though no single poison would fulfill all the characteristics mentioned in the table given above, a few examples mentioned are often considered.

questions.text: Identify the correct combination for A and B represented in the image:
questions.solution:
Sulfonamides are structural analogs of PABA and therefore inhibits the action of dihydropteroate synthase.

Trimethoprim inhibits dihydrofolate reductase and inhibits the formation of tetrahydrofolic acid. 

The combination of sulfonamides and trimethoprim causes sequential blockade and bacterial folate synthesis and results in greater efficacy and exteneded coverage.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles form the Passavant’s ridge?
questions.solution:
Passavant’s ridge is a mucosal ridge raised by the fibers of the palatopharyngeus. 

It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus. Soft palate, during its contraction makes firm contact with the ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during deglutition or speech.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding alpha fetoprotein?

choices.text: MSAFP is detected at 16-18 weeks of gestation
Diabetic patients have increased AFP levels
MSAFP is unrelated to period of gestation
Lowest fetal AFP is seen around 13 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15-20 weeks of gestation. Hence, it is detected in this period.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus. It is produced by the yolk sac and fetal liver. 

Option B: Diabetic patients have low levels of AFP. 

Option C: Gestational age influences the MSAFP levels. The maternal serum concentration increases by approximately 15% per week during the second trimester.

Option D: At about 13 weeks of gestation, the AFP concentration in the fetal serum and amniotic fluid are highest, after which it declines. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an upward elevation of the scapula relative to the thoracic cage characteristically seen in Sprengel deformity.

Sprengel deformity is a congenital upward elevation of the scapula. It is due to the failure of the scapula to descend completely in embryonic life.

The affected scapula is smaller, shaped differently, abnormally high, and somewhat prominent. Shoulder movements are usually painless. Abduction and elevation of shoulders may be limited due to fixation of the scapula.

The Cavendish classification is used to grade the severity of Sprengel deformity. 

If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. In severe deformity, surgery may be indicated. These procedures include:

  • Green procedure
  • Woodward procedure
  • Mears procedure

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl you examined in an outreach camp is found to have this abnormality. What is the most common site where the condition is seen?
questions.solution:
The condition depicted in the image is a coloboma of the iris, and the most common site of coloboma is the inferonasal quadrant.

A coloboma is a congenital malformation in one of the structures in the eye, such as the iris, retina, choroid, or optic disc, due to the failure of embryonic fissure closure. Coloboma of the uveal tract may be typical (seen in the inferonasal quadrant) or atypical (occasionally found in other positions). Typical coloboma is of two types: 

  • Complete: Extends from pupil to optic nerve, causing a corresponding lens indentation.
  • Incomplete: May involve iris alone, or iris and ciliary body (more common), or iris, ciliary body and a part of choroid.

Other embryonic remnants in the eye: 

  • Mittendorf's dot - Remnant of the anterior end of the hyaloid artery
  • Bergmeister papilla - Remnant of the posterior end of the hyaloid artery
  • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) - Failure of fetal vasculature to regress   

The image below shows a fundoscopy view of persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old farmer presented with a slow-growing lesion over his left hand for the past 5 months. The lesion was initially nodular, which then ulcerated. On examination, a 2 x 1 cm ulcer with everted margins was noted. Biopsy revealed keratin pearls. Which of the following stains will be positive for this condition?
  1. BCL2
  2. Cytokeratin 1
  3. CK-20
  4. HMB-45
  5. Cytokeratin 10
questions.solution:
SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinizing cells of the epidermis arising from the stratum germinatum (basalis) and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10.

CK-20 is specific for Merkel cell carcinoma. BCL2 is used to distinguish between basal cell carcinomas and trichoepitheliomas. HMB-45 is used to detect melanocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage?
questions.solution:
In triage, green signifies low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

An internationally accepted four-color coded system, with red having the highest priority is used commonly here.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A sexually active woman presented to a rural PHC with itching over the vulval region for a year. On examination, multiple lesions were noted over the vulva. Biopsy revealed cellular abnormality without stromal invasion involving the entire thickness of the vulva. What is the likely degree of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding of cellular abnormality involving the entire thickness of the vulva is suggestive of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) 3.

Degrees of vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN): 

Degree Cellular abnormality  Other features
VIN 1 Limited to the basal layer Lower 1/3rd of the vulval epithelium is involved
VIN 2

Basal & intermediate layer

Lower 2/3rd of vulval epithelium  is involved

Commonly associated with HPV
VIN 3

Entire thickness of the vulval epithelium is involved

No vascular/ lymphatic invasion

 2 types:

  • Young patients - HPV +ve, multiple lesions, 90% regress
  • Elderly patients - HPV –ve, single lesion, associated with lichen sclerosis, often progresses to invasive cancer

questions.text:
In which of the following patients would a lower amount of inhalational anesthetic be administered?
  1. 59-year-old chronic alcoholic
  2. 22-year-old addicted to cocaine
  3. 26-year-old pregnant lady
  4. 6-month-old infant
  5. 33-year-old man with serum calcium 12.5mg/dL
questions.solution:
Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) decreases in pregnancy and hypercalcemia. Thus, these patients require a lower dose of inhalational anesthetic agents.

Chronic alcoholics, infants, and people with a history of cocaine abuse would require higher doses of anesthetic agents.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC)

Hyperthermia >42°C Acute alcohol intoxication  Hyperthyroidism
Chronic alcohol abuse Hypothermia and hyperthermia up to 42°C Hypothyroidism

Drugs: Cocaine, Ephedrine Chronic amphetamine abuse  
Hypernatremia  Drugs: Opioids, Ketamine, Barbiturates, Benzodiazepines, Sympatholytics   
Young age (<6 months; MAC is maximum at 6 months) Hyponatremia, Hypercalcemia  
  Hypotension

  Pregnancy

questions.text: The weight of a diabetic woman is 75 kg and her  height is 150 cm. Calculate her BMI.
questions.solution:
The BMI of an individual with a weight of 75 kg and height of 150 cm is 33. It is calculated as follows,

BMI = Weight (in kg) / Height2 (in metre2) = 75 / (1.5)2 = 33.

Related Pearl: Body mass index

questions.text:
The intestinal biopsy report of a 7-year-old boy evaluated for chronic watery diarrhoea revealed a flat intestinal mucosa. Which of the following conditions would you suspect in this child?
  1. Tropical sprue
  2. Giardiasis
  3. Amoebiasis
  4. HIV enteropathy
  5. Neutrophilic gastroenteritis
questions.solution:
Chronic diarrhoea with a flat intestinal mucosa can be seen in conditions Tropical sprue, giardiasis, and HIV enteropathy.  

Causes of the flat intestinal mucosa (subtotal or total villous atrophy):

  1. Celiac disease
  2. Tropical sprue
  3. Giardiasis
  4. Bacterial overgrowth
  5. HIV enteropathy
  6. Eosinophilic gastroenteritis
  7. Cow’s milk or soy protein enteropathy
  8. Graft versus host disease
  9. Chemo or radiotherapy
  10. Protein-energy malnutrition
  11. Tuberculosis or lymphoma

Amoebiasis and neutrophilic gastroenteritis may also rarely have villous atrophy but the presentation is generally acute. Amoebiasis is characteristically associated with dysentery and biopsy would reveal a flask-shaped ulcer.

questions.text: A patient is referred to the ENT OPD with left-sided nasal obstruction, disfigurement of the face, and displacement of his left eye. Imaging of paranasal sinuses shows an ill-defined expanding lesion with ground glass appearance in the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia. A ground-glass appearance in CT or x-ray is characteristic of fibrous dysplasia.

In fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. The most common site is the maxillary sinus, followed by the ethmoid and frontal sinuses. 

It can present with disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction, and displacement of the eye.

The x-ray image below shows a ground-glass appearance present in the left maxillary sinus due to fibrous dysplasia. The lesion is not well demarcated and merges with the surrounding area. There is orbital displacement on the left side.

questions.text: Which of the following are components of definitive chorion?

choices.text: Extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast, and syncytiotrophoblast

questions.solution:
The definitive chorion consists of

  • Somatic (parietal) layer of extraembryonic mesoderm 
  • Cytotrophoblast
  • Syncytiotrophoblast

The chorion contributes to the fetal portion of the placenta, including the villi and villus lakes.

questions.text: What is the most common post-operative complication that may arise in patients who undergo an appendectomy ?
questions.solution:
Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendectomy.

Related Pearl: Complications of Appendicectomy

  • Wound infection: 5–10%
  • Intra-abdominal abscess: 8%
  • Post operative ileus
  • Respiratory complications
  • Venous thrombo-embolism
  • Portal pyemia- septicemia in portal venous system, can lead to hepatic abscess.
  • Adhesive intestinal obstruction: 1–3% (MC late post op complication)
  • Fecal fistula
  • Port site hernias.
  • Appendico-cutaneous fistula or appendico-vesical fistula: rare
  • Mortality after appendicectomy is less than 1%

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fibromuscular dysplasia is false?

choices.text: Most common histologic subtype is medial fibroplasia
Femoral artery is the limb artery most likely to be affected
The lesions of fibromuscular dysplasia are frequently bilateral tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery

questions.solution:
The iliac arteries are the limb arteries most likely to be affected by fibromuscular dysplasia.

The histologic classification of fibromuscular dysplasia:

  • Intimal fibroplasia (also classified as focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal)
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial dysplasia is subdivided into:

  • Medial fibroplasia (most common histologic subtype)
  • Perimedial fibroplasia
  • Medial hyperplasia.

Medial fibroplasia is the most common type

It is more common in females. The lesions of fibromuscular dysplasia are frequently bilateral and it tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery.

String of beads appearance is seen in angiography.

Clinical conditions in which String of pearls or string of beads sign is seen:

  • Fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Varicose bronchiectasis
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • Linear IgA disease
  • Small bowel obstruction

questions.text: Which of the following is not a core feature of Dementia with Lewy Body?
questions.solution:
Autonomic dysfunction is not a core feature of Dementia with Lewy Body(DLB).

Core features of DLB:

  • Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • Recurrent visual hallucinations, which are typically well-formed and detailed.
  • Spontaneous motor features of parkinsonism.
    • The most common - rigidity and bradykinesia, followed by hypophonic speech, masked facies, stooped posture, and a slow and shuffling gait.
    • Resting tremors may occur, but are less common.
  • Other supporting clinical features suggestive of DLB include REM sleep behavior disorder and severe neuroleptic sensitivity.
  DLB Parkinsonism
Resting tremor + +++
Temporal Relationship Dementia -> Parkinsonism Parkinsonism -> Dementia

Lewy bodies are composed predominantly of fibrillar deposits of α-synuclein, and can also include neurofilament proteins and ubiquitin.

Classic Lewy bodies: Inclusions with a hyaline core and pale halo are typically seen in the brain stem nuclei, substantia nigra, and locus coeruleus.

Cortical Lewy bodies: Less-well-defined spherical inclusions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding bacterial cell wall?

choices.text: Cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria is thicker than that of Gram-negative bacteria
Teichoic acid is present in cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria
Region II of LPS is core polysaccharide
LPS is responsible for O antigen specificity of gram negative bacteria

questions.solution:
Cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria

  • Peptidoglycan layer is thicker (15–80 nm) than gram negative bacteria (7.5–10nm)
  • Teichoic acid is present

Cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria

  • LPS present is responsible for endotoxic activity and O antigen specificity
  • It has 3 regions:
    • Region I - O polysaccharide determining O antigen specificity
    • Region II – core polysaccharide
    • Region III – Lipid A responsible for pyrogenicity, lethal effect, tissue necrosis, anticomplementary activity
  • Outer membrane
  • Lipoprotein
  • Peptidoglycan

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of blood in her urine. She informs you that this happens every month for 1 week and stops on its own. She underwent a C-section 1 year ago and has no history of incontinence. During clinical examination, a catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the catheter emerging from the cervical os. This, along with the history of cyclical hematuria, is suggestive of Youssef syndrome seen in a case of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistulas can develop after cesarean section, uterine rupture, and placenta accreta. Most cases present weeks to years later.

Vesicouterine fistulas can present with cyclical hematuria, urinary incontinence or complete continence, menstrual abnormalities, and urinary tract infections. Youssef syndrome is seen in cases of vesicouterine fistulas, and it is associated with a classic triad:

  • Amenorrhea
  • Cyclical hematuria - also called menouria: Menstrual blood trickles into the bladder through the fistula, causing hematuria
  • Urinary continence (there is no vaginal leakage of urine)

Hysteroscopy and cystoscopy are gold-standard investigations. 

Vesicouterine fistulas are treated as follows: 

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization - leads to spontaneous closure
  • Surgical repair via abdominal route

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not see on the skull X-ray of a patient with meningioma?
questions.solution:
Erosion is not an X-ray feature of meningioma.

. Skull X-ray findings in meningioma are:

  • Local hyperostosis - Thickening of skull bone 
  • Prominent frontal vascular markings - due to hypervascularity of the tumor
  • Calcification

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who was diagnosed with Sjogren's syndrome is on treatment with cevimeline. On which receptor does this drug mainly act for the expulsion of secretions from the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Cevimeline is an M3 receptor agonist resulting in the expulsion of the secretions from the salivary gland. This drug also enhances expulsion of lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome.

Both M1 and M3 receptors are present in a salivary gland. Activation of M1 increases secretion and M3 causes smooth muscle contraction and expulsion of the secretions.

Receptors of Parasympathetic system Subtype Site
Nicotinic Nm Neuromuscular junction
Nn CNS, ganglia, Adrenal gland
Muscarinic M1 CNS, Ganglia, Salivary, and gastric glands
M2 Heart
M3 Smooth muscles, secretory glands, eyes - pupils, and blood vessels
M4 CNS
M5 CNS

questions.text: Which of the following structures is the crus commune a part of?
questions.solution:
Crus commune is a part of the semicircular canals.

Each semicircular canal has 2 ends, ampullated & non-ampullated which open into the vestibule. The non-ampullated ends of posterior and superior canals unite to form a common channel called crus commune.

questions.text: Hassall corpuscles in thymus are composed of ________.
questions.solution:
Hassall corpuscles in the thymus are made up of whorls of medullary epithelial cells, with a central keratinized core.

Thymus structure:

  • The fully developed thymus is composed of two fused,well-encapsulated lobes. Fibrous extensions of the capsule divide each lobe into numerous lobules, each with an outer cortical layer enclosing the central medulla.
  • Diverse types of cells populate the thymus, but thymic epithelial cells and immature T lymphocytes, also called thymocytes, predominate.
  • The cortical, peripheral, epithelial cells are polygonal in shape and have an abundant cytoplasm with dendritic extensions that contact adjacent cells.
  • By contrast, the epithelial cells in the medulla are densely packed, often spindle-shaped, and have a scant cytoplasm devoid of interconnecting processes.
  • Whorls of medullary epithelial cells create Hassall corpuscles, with their characteristic keratinized cores.
  • Macrophages, dendritic cells, a minor population of B lymphocytes, rare neutrophils and eosinophils, and scattered myoid (muscle-like) cells are also found within the thymus.

Image shows histology of thymus with Hassall corpuscles in the medulla.

questions.text: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis and is associated with cholesterol stones.

Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.

Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.

Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.text: Which type of gastric ulcer has increased gastric acid levels?
questions.solution:
Gastric ulcers of Types II (gastric body with duodenal ulcer) and III (prepyloric) are associated with increased gastric acid levels.

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: Which of the following is not a stage of grief proposed by Kubler-Ross?
questions.solution:
Withdrawal is not a stage of grief according to the Kübler-Ross model. 

Related Pearl: The 5 stages of grief model by Kübler-Ross

  • Denial - Patients may become numb and dazed at the news of their own imminent death and refuse to accept the diagnosis. 
  • Anger - Patients may get angry towards God or themselves. 
  • Bargaining - Patients may start to bargain with God or friends and doctors for a cure to buy some more time.
  • Depression - Patients may go into depression.
  • Acceptance - Patients finally accept that their death is inevitable and make further preparations (eg., making a will, etc).

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to calculate the incidence of multifetal gestation?
questions.solution:
The incidence of multiple pregnancies is calculated by Hellin’s rule.

According to this rule, incidence= 1 : 80(n-1), where n is the number of fetuses.

Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies are:

  • Monozygotic
    • ART
  • Dizygotic
    • Race
    • Heredity
    • Maternal age
    • Parity
    • Family history of twinning
    • Good nutritional status
    • Infertility therapy

Option A: Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is calculated using ventricular doppler imaging. It is used to assess cardiac function in TTTS.

Option C: CHOP score is used for cardiac evaluation of recipient twin in TTTS.

Option D: Kleihauer-Betke test is used to evaluate the approximate volume of fetomaternal hemorrhage in cases of Rh-D alloimmunization.

questions.text: A woman presents with painful lesions, during the course of her treatment for leprosy, that resolve with medications, as seen below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in the borderline spectrum of disease
Systemic symptoms are not a feature
It presents with new red, painful lesions
Neuritis and nerve abscesses may occur

questions.solution:
The given scenario of painful lesions in the context of leprosy treatment is suggestive of type 1 lepra reaction, which presents with inflammation of existing skin lesions.

questions.text: Which  of the following is not a hepatic porphyria?
questions.solution:
Erythropoietic protoporphyria is not a type of hepatic porphyria. 

Porphyrias are classified into erythropoietic and hepatic porphyrias, based on the location of accumulation of heme pathway intermediates:

  1. Erythropoietic porphyrias:
    1. The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
    2. They are characterized by cutaneous symptoms and appear in early childhood.
    3. Examples: Congenital erythropoietic porphyria, erythropoietic protoporphyria, X-linked protoporphyria
  2. Hepatic porphyrias:
    1. The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
    2. Acute hepatic porphyrias are characterised by neurologic symptoms and present acutely. Examples: Acute intermittent porphyria, hereditary coproporphyria, variegate porphyria, ALA dehydratase deficient porphyria
    3. Chronic hepatic porphyrias present in adulthood with photosensitivity. Example: Porphyria cutanea tarda

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.
